any regularly or specially convened meeting of the President and Board of
Trustees of the Village or any subcommittee thereof;
   K.   During any regular or specially convened meeting of the President and
Board of Trustees or any committee, commission or board of the Village, or
during any regular or specially convened meeting of any other organization,
engages in the smoking of any cigarette, pipe and/or cigar;
   L.   Hinders, annoys or molests persons passing along any street, sidewalk,
crosswalk or other public way;
   M.   Loiters, sit, or stands around the entrance of any church, theater,
public building or other place of public assemblage in any manner so as to
unreasonably obstruct such entrance;
    N.   Places or erects upon any public way an obstruction of any type except
temporary barriers or warning signs placed thereon for the purpose of
safeguarding the public against any hazard;
   O.   Disturbs, threatens or in any insolent manner intentionally damages any
occupied house or vehicle;
   P.   Intentionally inhales vapors or fumes or any substance which induce
euphoria, hallucinations or intoxication except as otherwise provided by law;
   Q.   Visits or resorts to any place wherein the inhaling of vapors or fumes
or any substance which induces euphoria, hallucinations or intoxication is
being conducted, practiced or carried on illegally therein;
   R.   Makes continuous or causes to be made by the use of any horn, bell,
radio, loudspeaker or by operation of any other instrument or device any noise
or noises, which noise or noises are of such character, intensity and duration
as to disturb the peace and quiet of the Village or any portion thereof or to
be detrimental to the life and health of any individual;
   S.   Makes a telephone call, whether or not conversation ensues, with intent
to abuse, threaten or harass any person at the location of the telephone dialed
or called; or
   T.   Places graffiti upon the surface of any structure or wall that is
publicly or privately owned and wherein the contents thereof are visible to any
member of the general public. (For purposes of this subsection, the term
“graffiti” shall include but shall not be limited to the following illustrative
items: any drawing, inscription, word, phrase, diagram, symbol, sketch, or
letters containing references to sexual activity, diagrams relating to the
sexual activity or sexual organs, references to criminal activities, or groups
which promote or are involved in criminal activity, swearing or fighting words,
defamatory materials about any person or references to relationships.)
(Ord. 320, passed 6-14-95)
ARTICLE VI. OPEN FIRES
SECTION 7.601. OPEN FIRES.
   It shall be unlawful, within the corporate limits of the Village of Mettawa,
to cause, start, build, ignite, have and/or maintain any fire; except that this
prohibition shall not apply:
   A.   To fires for cooking food at public or private gatherings; and
   B.   To open fires.
(Ord. 322, passed 11-8-95)
SECTION 7.602. DEFINITION.
   For the purposes of this Article:
   OPEN FIRE. An intentionally ignited bonfire, grass fire, or other similar
burning conducted by any person in the open air or in an incinerator or similar
device where smoke, burning embers, or ash enter or discharge directly into the
open air.
(Ord. 322, passed 11-8-95)
ARTICLE VII. SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS
SECTION 7.701. VILLAGE POLICY ON SOLICITING AND CANVASSING.
   It is declared hereby to be the policy of the President and Board of
Trustees of the Village of Mettawa, the governing body of the Village, that the
occupant or occupants of buildings located in this Village, shall make the
determination of whether solicitors and canvassers shall be, or shall not be,
invited to their respective buildings.
(Ord. 661, passed 8-17-2010; Am. Ord. 798, passed 8-16-2016)
SECTION 7.702. PROHIBITION OF SOLICITING AND CANVASSING.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of soliciting
and/or canvassing upon premises within the corporate limits of the Village of
Mettawa wherein an owner or occupant has posted a notice at the principal
entrance of the building prohibiting solicitors or canvassers, as set forth in
Section
7.704(A).
(Ord. 661, passed 8-17-2010; Am. Ord. 798, passed 8-16-2016)
SECTION 7.703. NOTICE REGULATING SOLICITING AND CANVASSING.
   A.   Every owner or occupant desiring to secure the protection intended to
be provided by the regulations pertaining to soliciting and canvassing
contained in this Article shall give notice of the determination by the owner
or an occupant of giving invitation to solicitors and canvassers or the refusal
of invitation to solicitors and canvassers to any given building owned by such
owner or occupied by such occupant in the following manner:
      1.   A weatherproof card, no larger than three (3) inches by four (4)
inches in size, shall be exhibited upon or near the principal entrance door to
each such given building, indicating the determination by the owner or an
occupant containing the applicable words, as follows:
         a.   "NO SOLICITORS INVITED" or
         b.   "ONLY SOLICITORS REGISTERED WITH THE VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR
INVITED"
      2.   The letters on the weatherproof card shall be at least one-third ()
inch in height.
      3.   Such card as exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to any
solicitor and canvasser of the determination by the owner and/or any occupant
of the building of the information contained thereon.
   B.   In addition to the notice provided by such cards and not in
substitution thereof, an owner or occupant of land within the corporate limits
of the Village may provide an additional notification to solicitors and
canvassers in the following manner:
      1.   Such owner or occupant may erect one (1) sign no larger than one and
one-half (1½) square feet in overall size at the main driveway entrance to such
owner's or occupant's land.
      2.   The message on this sign shall be no different than the message on
the notice card exhibited upon or near the principal entrance door to the given
building or buildings on the land.
   C.   For the purpose of uniformity, the cards and signs utilized as a notice
or as an additional notification must be procured from the Village and shall be
provided at the cost thereof to Village residents upon request to the Village
Administrator.
(Ord. 661, passed 8-17-2010)
SECTION 7.704. DUTY OF SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS.
   A.   It shall be the duty of every solicitor and canvasser upon going onto
any premises in the Village of Mettawa upon which a building as herein defined
is located to first examine the premises for notice upon or near the principal
entrance door as provided in Section
7.703 and be governed by the statement contained on the notice. When a notice
is posted upon such premises if the notice states: “NO SOLICITORS OR
CANVASSERS”, then the solicitor, whether registered or not, shall immediately
and peacefully leave the premises.
   B.   Notwithstanding anything contained in this Article to the contrary, any
solicitor and/or canvasser who has gained entrance to any building, whether
invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when
requested to do so by any occupant thereof.
(Ord. 661, passed 8-17-2010; Am. Ord. 798, passed 8-16-2016)
SECTION 7.705. UNINVITED SOLICITING AND CANVASSING PROHIBITED.
   A.   It is declared hereby to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance
for any person, in defiance of the notice exhibited upon or near the principal
entrance door to a building, to remain upon such premises and ring the door
bell upon or near any door, or create any sound in any manner calculated to
attract the attention of any occupant of such building, for the purpose of
securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in soliciting and/or
canvassing.
   B.   Notwithstanding anything contained in this Article to the contrary, it
is declared hereby to be unlawful for any person to remain upon any premises
when requested to depart by any occupant thereof in accordance with the
provisions of Section
7.704.
(Ord. 661, passed 8-17-2010)
SECTION 7.706 LIMITATIONS ON SOLICITING AND CANVASSING.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, whether registered under this Article
or not, to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door of
a residence located thereon or rap or knock upon the door or create any sound
in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such
residence for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and
engage in soliciting prior to nine o’clock (9:00) A.M. or after five o’clock
(5:00) P.M. Monday through Saturday or at any time on a Sunday or a State or
national holiday, except in the case of canvassers which may not engage in
canvassing prior to nine o’clock (9:00) A.M. or after nine o’clock (9:00) P.M.
Monday through Friday and after six o’clock (6:00) P.M. on Saturday or at any
time on a Sunday or a State or national holiday.
(Ord. 661, passed 8-17-2010; Am. Ord. 798, passed 8-16-2016)
SECTION 7.707. APPLICATION FOR CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION.
   A.   Applicants seeking a certificate of registration issued by the Village
must first complete an application for such certificate at any time the Village
Administrator or the Village Clerk is on duty and working. The application
shall be made available by the Village Administrator or the Village Clerk upon
request.
   B.   Such certificate shall be in the form issued by the Village and, upon
receipt, shall entitle the holder thereof to solicit upon premises within the
Village wherein an owner or occupant has posted a notice upon or near the
principal entrance door to the principal entrance building inviting therein
only those solicitors who have registered with the Village.
   C.   All statements made by such applicant upon the application or in
connection therewith shall be under oath and shall truthfully state the
information requested on the application, as follows:
      1.   The applicant’s name;
      2.   The applicant’s residence address(es) during the past three (3)
years;
      3.   The applicant’s age, marital status; and if married, the name of the
applicant’s spouse;
      4.   The applicant’s height, weight and sex;
      5.   The name and address of the person by whom the applicant is employed
or represents and the length of time of such employment or representation;
      6.   The name and address of the applicant’s employer during the past
three (3) years if other than the present employer;
      7.   A description of the subject matter of the soliciting in which the
applicant will be engaged;
      8.   The length of time for which the certificate is requested;
      9.   The date, or approximate date, of the latest previous application
for a certificate under this Article, if any;
      10.   Whether a certificate of registration issued to the applicant has
ever been denied or revoked;
      11.   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of any
of the provisions of this Article, or the ordinance of any other Illinois
municipality regulating soliciting;
      12.   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission of
a felony under the laws of the State of Illinois or any other state or Federal
law of the United States; and
      13.   Such additional information as the Village may deem necessary to
process the application.
(Ord. 661, passed 8-17-2010; Am. Ord. 798, passed 8-16-2016)
SECTION 7.708. ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION.
   A.   Issuance of Certificate; Deposit:
      1.   When the applicant is found to be fully qualified, the certificate
of registration shall be issued forthwith and shall state the expiration date
thereof, which shall not exceed thirty (30) days from the date of issuance.
      2.   Upon receipt of the certificate of registration, the applicant shall
deposit the amount set forth in Chapter 2, Village Government, Article X, Tax,
Fee, Fine and Penalty Schedules, Section
2.1002, Fee Schedule, with the Village Administrator, which amount shall be
refunded at the time the certificate of registration is returned intact,
excluding reasonable wear and tear; provided the return is made not later than
five (5) days after the date of expiration of said certificate.
   B.   Denial of Certificate:
      1.   No certificate of registration shall be issued to any person who has
been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the State of
Illinois or any other state or Federal law of the United States within five (5)
years of the date of the application, nor to any person who has been convicted
of a violation of any of the provisions of this Article, nor to any person
whose certificate of registration issued hereunder has previously been revoked
as herein provided.
      2.   After a review of the application for registered solicitor and all
information obtained relative thereto, the Village Administrator shall deny the
issuance of a certificate of registration, if the Village Administrator finds
that the applicant does not possess the qualifications for such certificate of
registration as herein required and that the issuance of a certificate of
registration to the applicant would not be in accord with the intent and
purpose of this Article.
(Ord. 661, passed 8-17-2010; Am. Ord. 852, passed 10-20-2020)
SECTION 7.709. REVOCATION OF CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION.
   After its issuance, any certificate of registration issued hereunder shall
be revoked by the Village Administrator if the Village Administrator finds that
the holder of the certificate has made a false material statement in the
application.
   A.   Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given
by the Village Administrator to the holder of the certificate of registration
in person or by certified U.S. mail addressed to his or her residence address
set forth in the application.
   B.   Immediately upon the giving of such notice, the certificate of
registration shall become null and void; and, upon receipt of the notice, the
holder of the certificate shall surrender it to the Village Administrator.
(Ord. 661, passed 8-17-2010)
SECTION 7.710. RECORDS.
   The Village Administrator shall keep an accurate record of every application
received and acted upon, together with all other information and data
pertaining thereto, as well as a record of all certificates of registration
issued and denied under the provisions of this Article.
(Ord. 661, passed 8-17-2010)
SECTION 7.711. PENALTY.
   Every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this Article shall
be punished by a fine as set forth in Chapter 2, Village Government, Article X,
Tax, Fee, Fine and Penalty Schedules, Section
2.1003, Fine and Penalty Schedule.
(Ord. 661, passed 8-17-2010; Am. Ord. 852, passed 10-20-2020)
SECTION 7.712. SEVERABILITY.
   If any part or parts of this Article shall be held to be unconstitutional,
such unconstitutionality shall not affect the validity of the remaining parts
of this Article. The President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Mettawa
hereby declare that they would have adopted the remaining parts of this Article
if they had known that such part or parts thereof would be declared
unconstitutional.
(Ord. 661, passed 8-17-2010)
SECTION 7.713. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION AND DEFINITIONS.
   A.   The language set forth in the text of this Article shall be interpreted
in accordance with the following rules of construction: (a) The word "may" is
permissive and the word "shall" is mandatory; and (b) except where the context
reveals the contrary: The singular includes the plural and the plural includes
the singular, and the masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter.
   B.   Whenever in this Article the following words and phrases have been
used, they shall, for the purposes of this Article, have the meanings
respectively ascribed to them in this Subsection, except when the context
otherwise indicates.
      1.   APPLICANT.  A person seeking a certificate of registration.
      2.   APPLICATION. Provided by the Village Administrator, a form meeting
the requirements of Section
7.707 of this Article.
      3.   BUILDING. Any structure with substantial walls and roof securely
affixed to the land and entirely separated on all sides from any other
structure by space and which is designed or intended for the shelter, enclosure
or protection of human beings, animals or chattels; and includes a factory
manufactured building, or a prefabricated building on a site for more than one
hundred eighty (180) days.
      4.   CANVASS.  Going from door-to-door to engage in purely expressive
speech such as, but not limited to, advocacy for a particular religion,
philosophy, ideology, political party, issue, candidate, or other cause.
      5.   CANVASSER. A person, whether resident of the Village of Mettawa or
not, traveling either by foot, wagon, automobile, motor truck, or any other
type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to
street, taking a canvass or attempting to canvass.
      6.   CERTIFICATE or CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION. Issued by the Village
Administrator to an Applicant upon review and approval of the Applicant's
application, the certificate of registration authorized in this Article
allowing such Applicant to canvass or perform soliciting on real estate whereon
a notice is exhibited stating "ONLY SOLICITORS REGISTERED WITH THE VILLAGE
ADMINISTRATOR INVITED".
      7.   DWELLING, ONE-FAMILY DETACHED or SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENCE. A building
designed to contain one (1) dwelling unit which is entirely surrounded by open
area on the same lot and is not connected directly or indirectly to any other
dwelling unit by roof, walls, porches or any other means.
      8.   GAINED ENTRANCE. Having made one's way with the whole or part of
one's body, hand, foot, rock, projectile, weapon or other instrument into or
onto the real property of another.
      9.   NOTICE. A small sign meeting the requirements of this Article
containing the determination by the owner or an occupant of the building upon
which the sign is posted to invite or refuse to invite solicitors and
canvassers into the building upon which the sign is posted.
      10.   PERSON. A natural person, partnership, firm, corporation, or other
organization of any kind.
      11.   PREMISES. Any land including any dwelling, house, building or other
structure on such land, designed or used wholly or in part for private
purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or
vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps,
delivery vestibule, or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling,
house, building or other structure upon such land.
      12.   PRINCIPAL ENTRANCE. The main entrance to any single-family
residence upon the premises.
      13.   REAL PROPERTY or LAND. Any real estate, including improvements
thereon, and tangible personalty firmly affixed to the real estate.
      14.   SOLICITING.  Any one (1) or more of the following:
         a.   Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares,
merchandise, foodstuffs and/or services of any kind, character, or description
whatsoever, for any kind of consideration whatever;
         b.   Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or
purchase or insurance of any type or kind or character;
         c.   Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals,
newspapers and/or every other type or kind of publication; and/or
         d.   Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or
any other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any charitable or
nonprofit association, organization, corporation or project.
      15.   SOLICITOR. Any individual, including a canvasser, whether a
resident of the Village of Mettawa or not, traveling either by foot, wagon,
automobile, motor truck or any other type of conveyance, from place to place,
from house to house or from street to street, taking or attempting to take
orders for sale of goods, wares, and merchandise or other personal property of
any nature whatsoever for future delivery, or for services to be furnished or
performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes
for sale a sample of the subject of such sale or whether he is collecting
advance payment on such sales or not, provided that this definition shall
include any person, who for himself or for another person, hires, leases, uses,
or occupies any building, structure, tent, railroad box car, boat, hotel room,
lodging house, apartment, shop, or any other place within the Village for the
sole purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future delivery.
      16.   VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR.  The Village Administrator of the Village.
      17.   VILLAGE or VILLAGE OF METTAWA. The Village of Mettawa, an Illinois
municipal corporation and home rule unit as described in the Illinois
Constitution.
(Ord. 661, passed 8-17-2010; Am. Ord. 798, passed 8-16-2016)
ARTICLE VIII. MANDATES UNDER THE ILLINOIS FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT AND
ILLINOIS OPEN MEETINGS ACT
SECTION 7.801. FREEDOM OF INFORMATION OFFICER.
   A.   Effective on and after January 1, 2010, the Village Clerk shall be the
Freedom of Information Officer as required in section 3.5 of the Illinois
Freedom of Information Act (5 ILCS 140/3.5 - herein the "Freedom of Information
Act").
   B.   The Village Clerk may designate an individual or individuals (herein
collectively "Designee") to receive requests under the Freedom of Information
Act. Such designation is subject to the approval of the Village President and
Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 647, passed 1-12-2010)
SECTION 7.802. DUTIES OF FREEDOM OF INFORMATION OFFICER.
   A.   The Freedom of Information Officer, or the Designee thereof, shall
receive requests submitted to the Village under the Freedom of Information Act;
ensure that the Village responds to requests in a timely fashion and issue
responses under the Freedom of Information Act. The Freedom of Information
Officer shall develop a list of documents or categories of records that the
Village shall immediately disclose upon request and shall prepare other
documents required to be prepared in compliance with the Freedom of Information
Act.
   B.   Upon receiving a request for a public record, the Freedom of
Information Officer shall:
      1.   Note the date the Village receives the written request;
      2.   Compute the day on which the period for response will expire and
make a notation of that date on the written request;
      3.   Maintain an electronic or paper copy of a written request, including
all documents submitted with the request until the request has been complied
with or denied;
      4.   Create a file for the retention of the original request, a copy of
the response, a record of written communications with the requester, and a copy
of other communications.
(Ord. 647, passed 1-12-2010)
SECTION 7.803. DENIALS AND EXEMPTIONS.
   In issuing responses, the Freedom of Information Officer shall consult with
the Village Attorney to determine whether items are exempt from disclosure or
whether exempt matter should be redacted as part of a response to a Freedom of
Information request. In all instances where the Freedom of Information Act
allows the "public body" to deny or redact information which is exempt from
disclosure, the Freedom of Information Officer shall have the authority to make
such determinations following consultation with the Village Attorney as set
herein.
(Ord. 647, passed 1-12-2010)
SECTION 7.804. FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT TRAINING.
   As the Freedom of Information Officer, the Village Clerk shall comply with
the training requirements set forth in the Freedom of Information Act.
(Ord. 647, passed 1-12-2010)
SECTION 7.805. FEES.
   Except as otherwise provided by applicable statute, the Freedom of
Information Officer shall charge the fees for the copying of documents as set
forth in Chapter 2, Village Government, Article X, Tax, Fee, Fine and Penalty
Schedules, Section
2.1002, Fee Schedule.
(Ord. 647, passed 1-12-2010; Am. Ord. 852, passed 10-20-2020)
SECTION 7.806. DESIGNATED RECORD KEEPERS.
   Unless otherwise provided by applicable statute, the Village Clerk shall be
the keeper of records for the Village.
(Ord. 647, passed 1-12-2010)
SECTION 7.807. OPEN MEETINGS ACT TRAINING.
   A.   Persons Designated To Receive Training. The Village President, all
Trustees and the Village Clerk are designated hereby to receive the training
required under the Illinois Open Meetings Act (5 ILCS 120/1 et seq. - herein
the "Open Meetings Act"). This designation shall apply to the Village President
and Board of Trustees as well as to all standing and ad hoc committees,
commissions and boards of the Village (herein all such standing and ad hoc
committees, commissions and boards are collectively "Subordinate Public
Bodies") which may be considered a "public body" under the Open Meetings Act.
Subordinate Public Bodies shall not make additional designations.
   B.   Electronic Training. On or before June 30, 2010, or as may be extended
by the Illinois Public Access Counselor, the above designated persons must
successfully complete an electronic training curriculum, developed and
administered by the Public Access Counselor, and thereafter must successfully
complete an annual training program.
   C.   Newly Elected/Appointed/Hired Persons. Whenever any individual not
currently holding any of the designated offices of Village President or Trustee
or Village Clerk assumes any of those offices or whenever the President and
Board of Trustees designate by ordinance an additional officer or employee to
receive this training, such individual must successfully complete the
electronic training curriculum established by the Public Access Counselor
within thirty (30) days after assuming such designated office or position of
employment.
   D.   Designated Officers List. On or before July 1, 2010 and, thereafter,
within fifteen (15) days of an office-holder being designated to receive the
training required under the Open Meetings Act or assuming such designated
office, as the case may be, the Village Clerk shall submit a list of names of
such designated officers to the Public Access Counselor.
(Ord. 647, passed 1-12-2010)
SECTION 7.808. SEVERABILITY.
   In the event any part or parts of this Article shall be found
unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality
shall not affect the validity of the remaining parts of this Article.
(Ord. 647, passed 1-12-2010)
ARTICLE IX. ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION SYSTEM
SECTION 7.901. CREATION OF ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION SYSTEM.
   A.   Pursuant to Division 2.1 of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-
2.1-1, et seq., which authorizes municipalities to implement a system of
administrative adjudication, and pursuant to the home rule authority of the
Village, there is hereby created a system of administrative adjudication for
violations of the Village's Code of Ordinances. The system will authorize a
hearing officer to conduct adjudicatory hearings of violations of the Village
of Mettawa Code of Ordinances, as provided herein.
   B.   The adoption of this ordinance does not preclude the Village from using
other lawful methods to enforce the provisions of this code of ordinances.
(Ord. 892, passed 3-19-2024)
SECTION 7.902. JURISDICTION.
   The Administrative Adjudication Officer shall have jurisdiction over
adjudication all alleged violations of the Village Code of Ordinances,
including but not limited to the following code provisions:
   A.   Chapter 5, “Streets and Parks”;
   B.   Chapter 6, “Traffic”, except for any (i) any offense that is a traffic
regulation governing the movement of vehicles or (ii) any reportable offense
under Section 6-204 of the Illinois Vehicle Code;
   C.   Chapter 7, “Offenses and Miscellaneous Regulations”;
   D.   Chapter 9, “Building Code”;
   E.   Chapter 10, “Signs”;
   F.   Chapter 11, “Health and Sanitation”;
   G.   Chapter 12, “Animals”;
   H.   Chapter 15, “Zoning”;
   I.   Chapter 16, “Subdivision”;
   J.   Chapter 17, “Telecommunications”;
   K.   Chapter 18, “Alcoholic Beverages”;
   L.   Chapter 19, “Taxation”.
(Ord. 892, passed 3-19-2024)
SECTION 7.903. ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION ADMINISTRATOR.
   A.   There is established the position of Administrative Adjudication
Administrator who shall be appointed by the Village President. The
Administrative Adjudication Administrator's duties shall be to expedite the
prosecution and/or correction of Village Code violations subject to the
jurisdiction of the administrative adjudication system, including:
      1.   Operate and manage the system of administrative adjudication of
Village ordinance violations as may be permitted by law;
      2.   Promulgate rules and regulations reasonably required to operate and
maintain such system;
      3.   Distribute and process notices as may be required under this
ordinance or as may be reasonably required to carry out the purpose of this
ordinance;
      4.   Collect payments made as a result of fines and/or penalties assessed
after a final determination of liability;
      5.   Certify copies of findings, decisions and orders adjudicated
pursuant to this ordinance and verify the findings, decisions and orders that
are issued in accordance with this ordinance;
      6.   Certify reports to the Illinois Secretary of State concerning the
initiation of suspension of driving privileges in accordance with the
provisions of 625 ILCS 5/6-306.5; and
      7.   Keep records of appearances, and nonappearances; and
      8.   Pursue all post-judgment remedies available by law.
(Ord. 892, passed 3-19-2024)
SECTION 7.904. ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING OFFICER.
   A.   All adjudicatory hearings as provided by this article shall be presided
over by an administrative hearing officer who shall be appointed and removed by
the Village President. The administrative hearing officer shall be an
independent contractor of the village and shall not be considered an employee
of the village.
   B.   The administrative hearing officer shall be an attorney licensed to
practice law in the state for at least three (3) years who shall have
successfully completed a formal training program as required by law. The
village finds that a person chosen as a hearing officer for any administrative
adjudication undertaken by the village, who is otherwise qualified, shall have
fulfilled the education and training standards referenced herein as “formal
training program as required by law” if, at the time of his or her appointment,
that individual has served as a judge in the State of Illinois.
   C.   The administrative hearing officer shall have the following powers and
duties:
      1.   Hear testimony and accept evidence that is relevant to the existence
of the code violation;
      2.   Issue subpoenas directing witnesses to appear and give relevant
testimony at the hearing, upon the request of the parties or their
representatives;
      3.   Preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing and all exhibits
and evidence introduced at the hearing;
      4.   Issue written findings, decisions and orders stating whether a code
violation exists; and
      5.   Impose penalties consistent with applicable code provisions and
assess costs upon finding a party liable for the charged violation, except
however, that in no event shall the hearing officer have authority to impose a
penalty of incarceration or any other penalty in excess of that allowed by law.
Any such penalties imposed under this ordinance shall be exclusive of costs of
enforcement or costs or costs imposed to secure compliance with the code.
(Ord. 892, passed 3-19-2024)
SECTION 7.905. ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS UNDER THIS ARTICLE.
   A.   All administrative hearings shall be open to the public and shall be
presided over by a duly appointed administrative hearing officer who is charged
with providing the parties a full and fair opportunity to be heard.
   B.   All administrative hearings shall be conducted on the date set for
hearing. For good cause shown, a continuance may be granted at the discretion
of the administrative hearing officer. The purpose of administrative hearings
is to provide a prompt resolution of the alleged Code violation, and
accordingly, the request for and the grant of continuances shall be curtailed
to the extent fairness permits. Lack of preparation shall not be grounds for a
continuance. Continuances shall not be granted for more than twenty-eight (28)
days.
   C.   The formal and technical rules of evidence shall not apply in the
conduct of the hearing. Evidence, including hearsay, may be admitted if it is
of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of
their affairs.
   D.   No violation may be established except upon proof by a preponderance of
the evidence; provided, however, that the original or a legible copy of the
charging document, issued in accordance with the applicable provisions of this
Code, shall be prima facie evidence of the correctness of the facts specified
therein.
   E.   The Administrative Adjudication Administrator, with the advice and
consent of the administrative hearing officer, shall determine the manner in
which the record shall be preserved. Such preservation may be made by tape
recording or other appropriate means. Recording by any means by any member of
the public is prohibited unless expressly authorized by the Administrative
Adjudication Administrator. The record of all hearings before the
administrative hearing officer shall include a copy of the findings, decision,
and order of the administrative hearing officer's final determination.
   F.   At the conclusion of a hearing, the administrative hearing officer
shall issue his final determination. If the administrative hearing officer
issues a final determination of liability, a fine shall be imposed, consistent
with the specific Code provision(s) found to have been violated. If a
determination of liability is made against the violator, administrative costs
in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be imposed. All fines and
costs must be paid within seven days after the date of determination of
liability.
   G.   At the conclusion of the hearing, the administrative hearing officer
shall inform the parties orally of his determination and shall issue in writing
a final administrative decision which shall include written findings of fact, a
decision on whether a violation existed based upon the findings of fact and an
order including the fine, penalty or action which the defendant must comply, or
a dismissal of the case of no violation is proven. The final written decision
constitutes a final determination for purposes of judicial review and is
subject to review under the Illinois Administrative Review Law.
(Ord. 892, passed 3-19-2024)
SECTION 7.906 PROCEDURE.
   All matters to be adjudicated by the administrative hearing officer shall be
commenced against the party alleged to have violated one or more code
provisions by issuing and serving upon that party a charging document and shall
be conducted in accordance with the following procedures:
   A.   The charging document shall be issued by the administrative
adjudication village officer or person employee authorized to issue charging
documents.
   B.   Any charging document issued pursuant to this section shall contain the
following information:
      1.   The name, position, and identification number, if applicable, of the
person issuing the charging document;
      2.   The name and address of the person or entity being charged with one
or more code violations (“respondent”);
      3.   The name and address of the person to whom the charging document is
given if that person is not the respondent;
      4.   The section(s) of the code alleged to have been violated;
      5.   The date, time, and place of the alleged violation(s);
      6.   If a vehicle is involved, the vehicle make and state registration
number where available and readily discernible;
      7.   A description of the activity or conduct alleged to constitute a
violation of each code section set forth in the charging document or a
description of the facts giving rise to the allegations set forth in the
charging document; and
      8.   The date, time and place of the adjudicatory hearing to be held with
respect to the violation(s) alleged in the charging document.
   C.   The charging document shall be certified as to the correctness of the
information required by this subsection. The certification of correctness
required under this subsection shall establish prima facie evidence of the
correctness of the facts alleged in the violation notice. In the case of a
notice produced by a computer device, a single certificate may be signed and
kept by the Administrative Adjudication Administrator, attesting to the
correctness of all notices produced by the device while under his or her
control.
   D.   The administrative hearing shall be scheduled with reasonable
promptness, provided that for hearings scheduled in all non-emergency
situations, the respondent shall have at least fifteen (15) days after service
of process to prepare for a hearing if requested by the respondent. For
purposes of this subsection, “non-emergency situation” means any situation that
does not reasonably constitute a threat to the public interest, safety or
welfare.
   E.   The respondent named in a charging document, shall be given notice of
the date of the adjudicatory hearing which may appear on the face of the notice
of violation, citation, or other charging document. Notice of the hearing date
may be given in any of the following ways:
      (1)   By first class mail or by overnight or two-day commercial delivery
service at the respondent's last known address or if the respondent is a
business entity, at any address identified for its registered agent or at its
principal place of business; or
      (2)   By certified mail;
      (3)   By personal service;
      (4)   By any other means permitted by law for service of civil summons.
If service is provided by first class mail or by overnight or two-day
commercial delivery service or certified mail, the fifteen (15)-day period
shall begin to run on the day that the notice is deposited in the mail or given
to the commercial delivery service, as applicable.
   F.   The original or a legible copy of the notice of violation, citation, or
other charging document shall be filed with the administrative adjudication
administrator as soon as practicable at the place and in the manner as the
administrative adjudication administrator directs. Upon receiving the original
or legible copy of the charging document, the administrative adjudication
administrator shall select a hearing date and give respondent notice of the
date, time, and place of the hearing in the manner set forth in subsection
7.906E., unless the charging document sets forth the date, time, and location
of the hearing and was served personally on the respondent.
   G.   Parties to an adjudicatory hearing may be represented by an attorney or
other agent, present witnesses, and cross-examine opposing witnesses. Parties
may request the administrative hearing officer to issue subpoenas.
(Ord. 892, passed 3-19-2024)
SECTION 7.907 DEFAULT.
   If at the time set for hearing, the respondent, or his attorney or agent of
record, fails to appear, the administrative hearing officer may enter a default
judgment of liability against the respondent and impose fines and assess costs.
A copy of the order of default shall be served in any manner permitted by this
Article and applicable to the violation. A copy of the default judgment, which
constitutes a final determination for purposes of judicial review and is
subject to review under the Illinois Administrative Review Law, shall apprise
the respondent of the procedure for setting aside the default judgment and
shall also apprise the respondent of the availability of an appeal of the
default judgment to the Circuit Court of DuPage County.
(Ord. 892, passed 3-19-2024)
SECTION 7.908 JUDICIAL REVIEW.
   Any final decision of a hearing officer that a code violation does or does
not exist shall constitute a final determination for purposes of judicial
review under the Illinois Administrative Review Law. The findings, decision and
order of the hearing officer shall be subject to review in the Circuit Court of
DuPage County.
(Ord. 892, passed 3-19-2024)
SECTION 7.909 ENFORCEMENT.
   A.   Any fine, other sanction, or costs imposed, or part of any fine, other
sanction or costs imposed, remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of, or the
failure to exhaust, judicial review procedures under the Administrative Review
Law (735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.) shall be a debt due and owing the Village and,
as such, may be collected in accordance with applicable law.
   B.   After expiration of the period within which judicial review under the
Administrative Review Law (735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.) may be sought for a final
determination of the code violation, unless stayed by a court of competent
jurisdiction, the findings, decision and order of the hearing officer may be
enforced in the same manner as a judgment entered by a court of competent
jurisdiction.
   C.   In any case in which a respondent has failed to comply with a judgment
ordering a defendant to correct a code violation or imposing any fine or other
sanction as a result of a code violation, any expenses incurred by a
municipality to enforce the judgment, including, but not limited to, attorney's
fees, court costs, and costs related to property demolition or foreclosure,
after they are fixed by a court of competent jurisdiction or a hearing officer,
shall be a debt due and owing the municipality and may be collected in
accordance with applicable law. Prior to any expenses being fixed by a hearing
officer pursuant to this subsection C., the village shall provide notice to the
respondent that states that the respondent shall appear at a hearing before the
administrative hearing officer to determine whether the respondent has failed
to comply with the judgment. The notice shall set the date for such a hearing,
which shall not be less than seven (7) days from the date that notice is
served. If notice is served by mail, the seven (7) day period shall begin to
run on the date that the notice was deposited in the mail.
   D.   Upon being recorded in the manner required by Article XII of the Code
of Civil Procedure or by the Uniform Commercial Code, a lien shall be imposed
on the real estate or personal estate, or both, of the defendant in the amount
of any debt due and owing the municipality under this section. The lien may be
enforced in the same manner as a judgment lien pursuant to a judgment of a
court of competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. 892, passed 3-19-2024)
SECTION 7.910 FINES AND PENALTIES.
   A.   Fines and penalties may be imposed for violations as set forth in
Chapter 2, Article X, Section 2.1003.
   B.   For those violations for which a fine or penalty is not set forth in
Chapter 2, Article X, Section 2.1003, the fine shall be not less than one
hundred dollars ($100) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) for each
offense.
   C.   Each day that a violation of this Code of Ordinances exists shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 892, passed 3-19-2024)
ARTICLE X. FIREWORKS
SECTION 7.1001. FIREWORKS PROHIBITED.
   Within the corporate limits of the Village, it shall be unlawful for any
person to knowingly possess, manufacture, store, offer for sale, expose for
sale, sell at retail, use or explode and/or permit the use or explosion of any
fireworks upon land in which he has any leasehold, ownership or beneficial
interest.
(Ord. 607, passed 5-20-2008)
SECTION 7.1002. DEFINITIONS.
   A.   The language in this Article shall be interpreted in accordance with
the following rules of construction: (i) The word "may" is permissive and the
word "shall" is mandatory; and (ii) except where the context reveals the
contrary: The singular includes the plural and the plural includes the
singular, and the masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter.
   B.   When the following words are used in this Article, such words shall
have the following meanings:
      CLASS A FIREWORKS or CLASS A EXPLOSIVES. Dynamite.
      CLASS B FIREWORKS or CLASS B EXPLOSIVES or DISPLAY FIREWORKS. Those
fireworks that produce a visual or audible effect used for professional outdoor
displays and classified as fireworks UN0333, UN0334, or UN0335 by the United
States Department of Transportation Under 49 C.F.R. 172.101; and also sparkler
novelties, buzz bombs, helicopters, missiles, pin wheels and other twirling
devices whether mounted on the ground or above the ground, and planes.
      CLASS C FIREWORKS or CLASS C EXPLOSIVES or CONSUMER FIREWORKS. Those
common fireworks that produce a visual or audible effect and must comply with
the construction, chemical composition, and labeling regulations of the U.S.
Consumer Products Safety Commission, as set forth in 16 C.F.R. parts 1500 and
1507, and classified as fireworks UN0336 or UN0337 by the United States
Department of Transportation under 49 C.F.R. 172.101; and include road side
material, roman candles, Chinese firecrackers and all other firecrackers, hand
held fireworks, bottle rockets, sky rockets roman candles, chasers, etc. CLASS
C FIREWORKS or CONSUMER FIREWORKS shall not include snake or glow worm pellets;
smoke devices; trick noisemakers known as "party poppers", "booby traps",
"snappers", "trick matches", "cigarette loads", and "auto burglar alarms";
sparklers; toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns, or other devices in which paper or
plastic caps containing twenty-five hundredths grains or less of explosive
compound are used, provided they are so constructed that the hand cannot come
in contact with the cap when in place for the explosion; and toy pistol paper
or plastic caps that contain less than twenty hundredths grains of explosive
mixture; the sale and use of which shall be permitted at all times.
      FIREWORKS. Generically, any and all of Class A fireworks, Class B
fireworks and Class C fireworks.
      FIREWORKS USE ACT. The Illinois Fireworks Use Act found in the Illinois
Compiled Statutes at 425 ILCS 35/1 et seq.
      PERSON. Any individual, firm, co-partnership, corporation, association,
partnership, company, consortium, joint venture, or commercial entity owning or
having a beneficial interest in land upon which fireworks are displayed and/or
used and any individual, firm, co-partnership, corporation, association,
partnership, company, consortium, joint venture, or commercial entity who
conducts a display or uses fireworks.
      PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES. The President and Board of Trustees of
the Village.
      SPARKLER NOVELTIES. Shall mean and include any explosive composition or
any substance or combination of substances or articles prepared for the purpose
of producing a visible or audible effect of a temporary exhibitional nature by
explosion, combustion, deflagration or detonation and shall include any
cylindrical tube(s), cardboard or heavy cone containing pyrotechnics
composition including sparkler fountains, cone fountains, illuminating torches,
or filter sparklers; however, the term SPARKLER NOVELTIES shall not include
smoke devices; trick noise makers and sparkler devices, known as "sparklers",
consisting of a stick or wire coated with pyrotechnic composition not exceeding
3.5 ounces in weight per item; "party poppers", containing not more than .25
grains (16 mg) of explosive composition; "snappers" containing not more than
0.02 grains (1 mg) of explosive composition; and "snakes" containing not more
than 0.07 ounces (2 grams) of explosive composition.
      VILLAGE or VILLAGE OF METTAWA. The Village of Mettawa, an Illinois
municipal corporation and home rule unit as described in Article VII of the
Constitution of the State of Illinois.
(Ord. 607, passed 5-20-2008)
SECTION 7.1003. PENALTIES.
   Upon conviction: Any person who violates the provisions of Section
7.1001 of this Article shall be fined as set forth in Chapter 2, Village
Government, Article X, Tax, Fee, Fine and Penalty Schedules, Section
2.1003, Fine and Penalty Schedule. Each day that a violation of the provisions
of said Section
7.1001 exists shall constitute a separate violation. The foregoing
notwithstanding, any person found to be in violation of this Article shall
relinquish all fireworks in his possession to the Lake County Sheriffs Police
for destruction.
(Ord. 607, passed 5-20-2008; Am. Ord. 852, passed 10-20-2020)
ARTICLE XI. VIDEO GAMING
SECTION 7.1101. VIDEO GAMING PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS.
   A.   Pursuant to the authority vested in the corporate authorities of the
Village of Mettawa, as a home rule unit by Article VII of the Illinois
Constitution, and by Section 27 of the Illinois Video Gaming Act (230 ILCS 40/
27, the "Act"): it shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to
install, operate and/or offer for use within the corporate limits of the
Village any video gaming terminal, whether or not such premises where such
terminal may be located is a licensed establishment or a licensed fraternal
establishment or a licensed veterans establishment or truck stop establishment,
as such terms are defined in the Act.
   B.   Nothing in this Section shall prohibit distributors, manufacturers or
suppliers from distributing, manufacturing or supplying video gaming terminals
for use and/or operation outside of the corporate limits of the Village.
(Ord. 634, passed 9-15-2009)
SECTION 7.1102. VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES.
   A.   Upon conviction: Any person who violates the provisions of Section
7.1101 of this Article shall be fined as set forth in Chapter 2, Village
Government, Article X, Tax, Fee, Fine and Penalty Schedules, Section
2.1003, Fine and Penalty Schedule, for each and every offense, depending upon
the frequency of the violations; and each day that a violation of the
provisions of said Section
7.1101 exists shall constitute a separate violation.
   B.   In addition to the penalty set forth above, the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner may suspend or revoke any liquor licensee’s license for any
violation of any provision of this Ordinance, or for any violation of the Act
or other State law pertaining to video gaming.
(Ord. 634, passed 9-15-2009; Am. Ord. 852, passed 10-20-2020)
ARTICLE XII. PUBLIC CONTRACT GUIDELINES
SECTION 7.1201. FORMAL CONTRACT PROCEDURE.
   All work or other public improvement which is not to be paid for in whole or
in part by special assessment and all purchases of and contracts for supplies
and services, except as otherwise provided herein, when the estimated cost
thereof shall exceed Thirty Thousand Dollars ($30,000), shall be purchased by
formal, written contract entered into with the low responsible bidder, after
due notice inviting bids, unless competitive bidding is waived by a vote of the
President and Board of Trustees of the Village.
(Ord. 677, passed 12-21-2010; Am. Ord. 881, passed 6-20-2023)
SECTION 7.1202. NOTICE INVITING BIDS.
   Notice inviting bids shall be published at least once in a newspaper having
a general circulation within the Village. This newspaper notice shall include a
general description of the work to be performed or the articles to be
purchased, shall state where specifications, if any, may be secured; as well as
the times and places for submitting and opening bids.
(Ord. 677, passed 12-21-2010)
SECTION 7.1203. SPECIFICATIONS.
   The Village Engineer shall be responsible for preparing bid specifications
in cases involving public works projects, including maintenance projects. In
all cases when specifications are provided by the Village, the specifications
shall include a form of contract which has been approved by the Village
Attorney. The contract form shall include the following clauses:
   A.   Each party hereto certifies hereby that it is not barred from entering
into this Agreement as a result of violations of either Sections 33E-3 or 33E-
4 of the Illinois Criminal Code (720 ILCS 5/33 -E-3, 5/33-E-4), that it has a
written policy against sexual harassment in place in full compliance with 775
ILCS 5/2-105(A)(4), and it is in compliance with the Illinois Drug Free
Workplace Act (30 ILCS 580/2).
   B.   The contractor does hereby swear and affirm that: (a) it is not
delinquent in the payment of any tax administered by the Illinois Department of
Revenue; or (b) the contractor is contesting, in accordance with the procedures
established by the appropriate revenue statute, the liability for the tax or
the amount of the tax; and (c) the contractor further understands that making a
false statement herein is a Class I Misdemeanor that voids this agreement and
allows the Village to recover all amounts payable to it under this agreement.
(Ord. 677, passed 12-21-2010)
SECTION 7.1204. BID DEPOSITS.
   When deemed necessary by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village,
bid deposits shall be prescribed in the public notice inviting bids.
Unsuccessful bidders shall be entitled to return of their bid deposits upon the
award of the contract by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village. A
successful bidder shall forfeit any bid deposit required by the President and
Board of Trustees of the Village upon failure on his part to enter into a
contract after the award within the time specified, unless such period is
extended by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village.
(Ord. 677, passed 12-21-2010)
SECTION 7.1205. BID OPENING PROCEDURE.
   Any contractor responding to a request for proposals that requires sealed
bids shall submit a sealed bid to the Village as specified and shall identify
its bid as such on the sealed envelope.
   A.   Opening. Sealed bids shall be opened in public at the time and place
stated in the public notice.
   B.   Tabulation. Following opening, such bids shall be tabulated by the
Village Engineer and the tabulation of the bids furnished to the President and
Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 677, passed 12-21-2010)
SECTION 7.1206. REJECTION OF BIDS.
   A.   In all cases, the President and Board of Trustees have the right to
reject all bids or parts of all bids, whether or not such right is reserved in
the specifications.
   B.   The Village shall not accept the bid of a contractor who is in default
on the payment of taxes, licenses or other monies due the Village or who cannot
make the certifications contained in Section
7.1203.
(Ord. 677, passed 12-21-2010)
SECTION 7.1207. AWARD OF CONTRACTS.
   A.   The President and Board of Trustees of the Village has the authority to
award contracts in accordance with the terms of this Article.
   B.   Contracts shall be awarded to the low responsible bidder as determined
by the President and Board of Trustees. In awarding the contract, in addition
to price, the President and Board of Trustees of the Village shall consider.
      1.   The ability, capacity and skill of the bidder to perform the
contract to provide the service required;
      2.   Whether the bidder can perform the contract or provide the service
promptly, or within the time specified, without delay or interference;
      3.   The character, integrity, reputation, judgment, experience and
efficiency of the bidder;
      4.   The quality of performance of previous contracts or services;
      5.   The previous and existing compliance by the bidder with laws and
ordinances relating to the contract or service;
      6.   The sufficiency of the financial resources and ability of the bidder
to perform the contract or provide the service;
      7.   The quality, availability and adaptability of the supplies or
contractual services to the particular use required;
      8.   The ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service
for the use of the subject of the contract;
      9.   The number and scope of conditions attached to the bid;
      10.   Whether the bidder has a place of business in the Village; and/or
      11.   Any other matter deemed pertinent to the President and Board of
Trustees.
   C.   Performance Bonds. The President and Board of Trustees of the Village
has the authority to require a performance bond, before entering into a
contract, in such amount as it shall find reasonably necessary to protect the
best interests of the Village.
(Ord. 677, passed 12-21-2010)
SECTION 7.1208. OPEN MARKET PROCEDURE.
   All work and purchases of supplies and services of less than the estimated
value of Twenty Thousand Dollars ($20,000) shall be made in the open market,
without the necessity of newspaper advertisement and without observing the
procedure prescribed by this Article for the award of formal contracts.
(Ord. 677, passed 12-21-2010)
SECTION 7.1209. CONTRACTS OR PURCHASES WITHOUT BID.
   Any requirement to contract for work supplies or services as provided in
this Article XII, shall not apply to the following:
   A.   All contracts for professional services, including but not limited to
architects, attorneys, engineers, land planners, real estate appraisers, or
other individuals possessing a high degree of skill where the ability or
fitness of the person is an important requirement;
   B.   Purchases which may only be made from a single source;
   C.   Purchases, which because of the unique characteristics of the personal
property or the needs of the village, are not susceptible to competitive
bidding;
   D.   Contracts extended pursuant to options to renew for additional periods
of time at a fixed price; and
   E.   Extension of contracts that have originally been bid and can be renewed
for an additional period of time at a competitive fixed price.
(Ord. 677, passed 12-21-2010; Am. Ord. 881, passed 6-20-2023)
SECTION 7.1210. EMERGENCY PURCHASES.
   In case of a real or a perceived emergency requiring immediate services or
purchase of supplies, the President and Board of Trustees of the Village may
authorize the securing of a contract for the work or supplies at the low
obtainable price by the open market procedure as herein set forth, regardless
of the amount of the expenditure.
(Ord. 677, passed 12-21-2010)
SECTION 7.1211. COOPERATIVE PURCHASING.
   The President and Board of Trustees of the Village retain the right to join
with other units of government in cooperative purchasing plans.
(Ord. 677, passed 12-21-2010)
SECTION 7.1212. CHANGE ORDERS.
   Except as hereinafter provided, all change orders to construction contracts
originally awarded by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village must
receive approval from the President and Board of Trustees of the Village.
However, the Village Administrator is authorized hereby to approve and accept
any change order that will: 1) not affect the contract price; 2) lower the
contract price; or 3) not increase the contract price by an amount in excess of
Five Thousand Dollars ($5,000).
(Ord. 677, passed 12-21-2010; Am. Ord. 881, passed 6-20-2023)
ARTICLE XIII. POLICY: UNPAID CHARGES AND ASSESSMENTS AND DISCLOSURE OF
INTERESTS
SECTION 7.1301. CERTIFICATE OF NO UNPAID CHARGES AND ASSESSMENTS.
   A.   Prior to the issuance by any Village official or agent of any Village
certificate real estate transfer tax stamp, license and/or permit required to
be issued pursuant to the laws and ordinances of the Village of Mettawa, such
official or agent shall withhold such issuance until the applicant seeking such
certificate, license and/or permit shall have paid in full any and all overdue
unpaid fees or charges for any Village provided service and/or any unpaid
fines, judgments, levies, debts or required reimbursements to be made to the
Village.
   B.   No Village official or agent whose duty it is to issue such
certificate, license and/or permit shall issue such certificate, license and/or
permit until such time as the applicant seeking such certificate, license and/
or permit presents to such Village official or agent the certificate of the
Village Clerk indicating that all such fees and charges, fines, judgments,
levies, debts or required reimbursements have been paid in full or are non-
existing.
   C.   In the case of the collection of real estate transfer taxes, no real
estate transfer stamp shall be issued until the grantor and grantee each shall
have certified to the Village official or agent whose duty it is to issue
transfer stamps that, to the best of the knowledge and belief of each, there
are no other unpaid fees or charges for any Village provided service and/or any
fines, judgments, levies, debts or required reimbursements to be paid to the
Village by the grantor and/or the grantee or in any manner arising out of or
pertaining to the real property which is the subject of such transfer.
(Ord. 677, passed 12-21-2010; Am. Ord. 713, passed 12-13-2011)
SECTION 7.1302 DISCLOSURE OF INTERESTS REQUIRED.
   Whenever any person makes application to the Village for any benefit, being
any authorization, certificate, real estate transfer tax stamp, zoning and/or
subdivision consideration, license and/or permit, whether or not relating to
real estate:
   A.   Such person shall certify whether such person is acting in his own
behalf or as an agent, officer or trustee.
   B.   If such person certifies he is (i) an agent, (ii) a trustee or a
beneficiary of a trust, or (iii) an officer of or for any firm or corporation,
such person shall identify by name and address each and every:
      1.   Principal for whom he is acting as agent and describe such
principal's interest in such benefit.
      2.   Beneficiary of such trust of which he is beneficiary or acting as
trustee and describe each such beneficiary's interest in such trust; and
provide a certified copy of such trust agreement.
      3.   Person having a five percent (5%) or greater ownership interest in
the firm or corporation.
   C.   In addition to the foregoing, if such benefit relates to real estate,
such person shall also identify such real estate by its commonly known Village
address as well as its legal description and permanent index number.
SECTION 7.1303. VIOLATION; PENALTY.
   A.   Every person convicted of a violation of any of the provisions on this
Section shall be punished by a fine as set forth in Chapter 2, Village
Government, Article X, Tax, Fee, Fine and Penalty Schedules, Section
2.1003, Fine and Penalty Schedule.
   B.   For purposes of this Article, each day that a violation is permitted to
exist shall constitute a separate offense.
   C.   The remedies afforded by this Section are in addition to any and all
other remedies afforded the Village of Mettawa and its residents by law and
shall not be deemed to preclude pursuit of such other remedies.
(Ord. 713, passed 12-13-2011; Am. Ord. 852, passed 10-20-2020)
ARTICLE XIV. ADULT-USE CANNABIS BUSINESS ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION 7.1401. DEFINITIONS.
   The following words and phrases shall, for the purposes of this Chapter,
have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section, as follows:
   ADULT-USE CANNABIS BUSINESS ESTABLISHMENT: A cultivation center, craft
grower, processing organization, infuser organization, dispensing organization
or transporting organization.
   ADULT-USE CANNABIS CRAFT GROWER: A facility operated by an organization or
business that is licensed by the Illinois Department of Agriculture to
cultivate, dry, cure and package cannabis and perform other necessary
activities to make cannabis available for sale at a dispensing organization or
use at a processing organization, per the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act,
(P.A. 101-0027), as it may be amended from time-to-time, and regulations
promulgated thereunder.
   ADULT-USE CANNABIS CULTIVATION CENTER: A facility operated by an
organization or business that is licensed by the Illinois Department of
Agriculture to cultivate, process, transport and perform necessary activities
to provide cannabis and cannabis-infused products to licensed cannabis business
establishments, per the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act, (P.A. 101-0027), as it
may be amended from time-to-time, and regulations promulgated thereunder.
   ADULT-USE CANNABIS DISPENSING ORGANIZATION: A facility operated by an
organization or business that is licensed by the Illinois Department of
Financial and Professional Regulation to acquire cannabis from licensed
cannabis business establishments for the purpose of selling or dispensing
cannabis, cannabis-infused products, cannabis seeds, paraphernalia or related
supplies to purchasers or to qualified registered medical cannabis patients and
caregivers, per the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act, (P.A. 101-0027), as it may
be amended from time-to-time, and regulations promulgated thereunder.
   ADULT-USE CANNABIS INFUSER ORGANIZATION OR INFUSER: A facility operated by
an organization or business that is licensed by the Illinois Department of
Agriculture to directly incorporate cannabis or cannabis concentrate into a
product formulation to produce a cannabis-infused product, per the Cannabis
Regulation and Tax Act, (P.A. 101-0027), as it may be amended from time-to-
time, and regulations promulgated thereunder.
   ADULT-USE CANNABIS PROCESSING ORGANIZATION OR PROCESSOR: A facility operated
by an organization or business that is licensed by the Illinois Department of
Agriculture to either extract constituent chemicals or compounds to produce
cannabis concentrate or incorporate cannabis or cannabis concentrate into a
product formulation to produce a cannabis product, per the Cannabis Regulation
and Tax Act, (P.A. 101-0027), as it may be amended from time-to-time, and
regulations promulgated thereunder.
   ADULT-USE CANNABIS TRANSPORTING ORGANIZATION OR TRANSPORTER: An organization
or business that is licensed by the Illinois Department of Agriculture to
transport cannabis on behalf of a cannabis business establishment or a
community college licensed under the Community College Cannabis Vocational
Training Pilot Program, per the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act, (PA 101 -
0027), as it may be amended from time-to-time, and regulations promulgated
thereunder.
   PERSON: Any person, firm, corporation, association, club, society or other
organization, including any owner, manager, proprietor, employee, volunteer or
agent.
(Ord. 841, passed 10-15-2019)
SECTION 7.1402. CANNABIS BUSINESS ESTABLISHMENTS PROHIBITED.
   The following Adult-Use Cannabis Business Establishments are prohibited in
the Village. No person shall locate, operate, own, suffer, allow to be operated
or aide, abet or assist in the operation within the Village any of the
following:
   Adult-Use Cannabis Craft Grower
   Adult-Use Cannabis Cultivation Center
   Adult-Use Cannabis Dispensing Organization
   Adult-Use Cannabis Infuser Organization or Infuser
   Adult-Use Cannabis Processing Organization or Processor
   Adult-Use Cannabis Transporting Organization or Transporter
(Ord. 841, passed 10-15-2019)
SECTION 7.1403. PUBLIC NUISANCE DECLARED.
   Operation of any prohibited Cannabis Business Establishment within the
Village in violation of the provisions of this article is hereby declared a
public nuisance and shall be abated pursuant to all available remedies.
(Ord. 841, passed 10-15-2019)
SECTION 7.1404. VIOLATIONS.
   Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be subject to a
fine in the amount of not less than $750 or more than $1,000.00 per offense. A
separate offense shall be deemed to have been committed on each day during
which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 841, passed 10-15-2019)

   ARTICLE I. ADMINISTRATION
SECTION 8.101. SCOPE.
   A.   The owner of a structure on a lot in the Village of Mettawa who
requires sanitary sewage service shall, at his own expense, construct and
maintain a Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System meeting the
applicable regulations of the County of Lake and applicable ordinances of the
Village of Mettawa, unless the Village of Mettawa has authorized and
constructed a public sanitary sewer to provide service to the lot. If a Private
Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System should fail, and cannot be repaired,
an Expansion System as regulated by this Municipal Code shall be constructed,
or if such construction is impossible, an experimental system approved by the
Lake County Health Department and the Village of Mettawa shall be constructed.
   B.   Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal Systems are required unless
the Village of Mettawa has authorized and constructed a public sanitary sewer
to provide service to the lot. Unless specifically approved by the Village
Engineer, the Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System of each building
shall be entirely separate from and independent of that of any other building.
   C.   This Chapter is enacted in order to secure the proper design and
installation of septic systems for the treatment and disposal of sewage; to
insure minimum standards for sewage discharges, the location, installation,
alteration, operation, maintenance, and monitoring of all Private Individual
Onsite Sewage Disposal Systems so as to protect land, water, groundwater and
other natural resources within the Village of Mettawa from impairment,
pollution, or destruction; to minimize the risk of spreading communicable
diseases, and to prevent and avoid other health and ecologic hazards
attributable to bacteria, viruses, protozoa and the helminths, as well as,
chemical contamination of lands and waters.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.102. APPLICABILITY.
   A.   General. The provisions of these regulations shall cover all matters
affecting or relating to Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal Systems as
set forth in this Chapter.
   B.   Matters Not Provided For. Any private sewage disposal requirement
essential for the sanitary safety of an existing or proposed building or
structure or essential for the health or safety of the occupants thereof, and
which is not specifically covered by this Code, shall be determined by the
Village Engineer.
   C.   Continued Use. The continuation of use of a private sewage disposal
system, or part thereof, contrary to the provisions of this Chapter shall be
deemed a violation, and subject to the penalties prescribed in Article XIV.
   D.   Referenced Standards. The standards referenced in this Chapter and
listed in Appendix A shall be considered part of the requirements of this
Chapter to the prescribed extent of each reference. Where differences occur
between provisions of this Chapter and referenced standards, the provisions of
this Chapter shall apply.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.103. VALIDITY.
   A.   Partial. In the event any part or provision of this Chapter is held to
be illegal or void, such finding shall not have the effect of making void or
illegal any of the other parts or provisions thereof, which are determined to
be legal, and it shall be presumed that this Chapter would have been approved
without such illegal or invalid parts or provisions.
   B.   Segregation. Any invalid part of this Chapter shall be segregated from
the remainder of the Chapter by the court holding each part invalid, and the
remainder shall remain effective.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.104. DUTIES AND POWERS OF THE VILLAGE ENGINEER.
   A.   General. The Village Engineer shall enforce all of the provisions of
this Chapter and shall act on any question relative to the mode or manner of
the design or construction and the materials to be used in the installation of
Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal Systems and shall specifically act as
follows.
   B.   Applications and Permits. The Building Official shall receive
applications and issue building permits following approval of the plans for the
installation of private sewage disposal systems by both the Village Engineer
and the Health Officer. The Village Engineer and the Health Officer shall
inspect the premises for which such permits have been issued, and enforce
compliance with the provisions of this Chapter.
   C.   Notices and Orders. The Village Engineer and/or the Building Official
shall issue all necessary notices or orders to remove illegal or unsafe
conditions, to require the necessary safeguards during construction, and to
insure compliance with all Chapter requirements. Any written order posted on
premises involved shall not be removed except by order of the Village Engineer.
Removal without such order shall constitute a violation of this Chapter to
ensure the health, safety and general welfare of the public. The Building
Official and/or the Village Engineer may revoke, by writing, any permit or
approval issued contrary to this Chapter or based upon a false statement or
misrepresentation in the application.
   D.   Authority to Enter Premises. The Health Officer, the Building Official
and/or the Village Engineer, after identification, shall have the authority to
enter any property at any reasonable time to inspect any premises for health
and sanitation purposes, and for compliance with the provisions of this
Chapter. The Health Officer and/or the Village Engineer may also make any
necessary test, including dye tests or obtaining effluent samples for
laboratory analysis, on any property to determine compliance with the
provisions of this Chapter. The Village Engineer is authorized to engage such
expert opinion as deemed necessary to report upon unusual technical issues that
arise.
   E.   Official Records. The Building Official shall keep official records of
applications received, permits and certificates issued, fees collected, reports
of inspections, and notices and orders issued. Such records shall be retained
in the official records so long as the building or structure to which they
relate remains in existence unless otherwise provided for.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.105. EXISTING SYSTEMS.
   A.   Continued System Use. The legal use and occupancy of any structure
serviced by a Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System, which had been
heretofore approved, shall be permitted to be continued without change, except
as specifically addressed in this Chapter.
   B.   System Maintenance. All Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal
Systems, both existing and new, shall be maintained in a safe and sanitary
condition. All service equipment, devices and safeguards which are required by
this Chapter, or which were required by previous statute, shall be maintained
in working order as when installed or repaired.
   C.   Maintenance Responsibility. The owner or the owner's designated agent
shall be responsible for the safe and sanitary maintenance of the Private
Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System for any building or structure at all
times.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
   ARTICLE II. DEFINITIONS
SECTION 8.201. GENERAL.
   A.   Whenever in this Chapter the following words and phrases are used, they
shall, for the purposes of this Chapter, have the meanings ascribed to them in
this Article, except when the context otherwise indicates. The masculine gender
includes the feminine and neuter, and the singular number shall include the
plural number. The word "shall" is mandatory, the word "may" is permissive.
   B.   Where terms are not defined through the methods authorized by this
Article, such terms shall have ordinarily accepted meanings such as the context
implies.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.202. DEFINITIONS.
   BATHROOM. A room containing toilet facilities and includes any of the
following:
      •   HALF BATHROOM or POWDER ROOM. A room containing a flush toilet and a
vanity.
      •   FULL BATHROOM. A room containing at least a flush toilet, a bathtub
or whirl pool, and a vanity.
      •   THREE-QUARTER BATHROOM. A room containing a flush toilet, a shower
and a vanity.
      •   PRIVATE BATHROOM. A three-quarter bathroom or full bathroom having
limited access via a bedroom only.
   BEDROOM. Any room, regardless of its designation by the owner or permit
applicant or anyone else, which may be used regularly for sleeping. Extra rooms
shall be considered bedrooms if there exists in the same story either a full
bathroom or a three-quarter bathroom or both, excluding bedrooms with a private
bathroom.
   BUILDABLE AREA. For purposes of this Chapter, the minimum 30,000 square foot
area of a lot designated for use as a Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal
System leaching field, which area shall not lie within any zoning yard and
shall otherwise comply with other setback and soil suitability requirements.
   BUILDING OFFICIAL. The Building Official of the Village of Mettawa or his
designated agent.
   CLASS I AEROBIC UNIT. A mechanical wastewater treatment unit which is listed
by NSF International as Class I.
   COARSE SAND. Fill material having an effective diameter of .15 to .30 mm
with a coefficient of uniformity <5.0, and having less than 20% material
coarser than 2 mm and less than 5% silt and clay.
   CONSTRUCTION PERMIT. A non-transferable permit issued by the Lake County
Health Department to a licensed Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal
System contractor to construct a Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal
System to the specifications of the plan approved for the septic system.
   DISCHARGE RATE. The volume of wastewater discharged from a low pressure
distribution septic system expressed as gallons per minute, and applied as a
rate either per perforation, per line, or per septic system.
   DISTAL END PRESSURE. A measure of septic system pressure in a low pressure
distribution septic system made at the end of a lateral distribution pipe
opposite pressure head.
   DIVERTER VALVE. A valve with a single inflow which may be adjusted to direct
outflow into any one of two or more directions.
   DOMESTIC SEWAGE. Wastewater typical of a residential flow, containing human
wastes, moderate concentrations of soaps and detergents, and minimum
concentrations of grease and toxics such as normal household cleaning agents.
   EFFLUENT FILTER. A device installed at the outflow of a septic tank which
screens and collects solids ordinarily suspended in solution.
   EXPANSION AREA. An area equal to or greater in size to the primary area,
located in a site, and designated for construction of an Expansion System upon
the replacement or enlargement of a soil based Private Individual Onsite Sewage
Disposal System.
   EXPANSION SYSTEM. An additional septic system which must be constructed on
the site upon the failure of the primary system and/or the construction of a
guest house or additional bedrooms on the lot.
   EXTRA ROOMS. Unfinished or finished rooms that may be used as dens, studies,
bonus rooms, libraries, television rooms, sewing rooms and similar rooms.
   FINISHED. Walls of room, the surface of which is plaster or taped dry-wall
or paneling.
   FLOODPLAIN. The elevation of base flood elevation expressed as U.S.
Geological Survey (mean sea level) National Geodetic vertical datum, which
establishes the 100 year flood limit, and adjacent lands of equal or lower
elevation.
   FLOW CONTROL DEVICE. A device specially designed to equalize the outflow
elevation of effluent from a distribution box typically a rotating pipe cap
provided with an off center outflow orifice which can adjust the flowline by
rotation of the cap.
   HEALTH OFFICER. The Executive Director of the Lake County Health Department
or an appropriate designated agent thereof.
