   IRRIGATION or SPRAY IRRIGATION. The moistening of the surface of land with
treated or untreated sanitary sewage and includes any land treatment type
sanitary sewage facility whether or not such facility has received the
approvals required by the Northeastern Illinois Planning Commission, or the
Illinois Environmental Protection Agency or any other governmental entity, but
excluding Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal Systems.
   ISOLATION DISTANCE. The vertical measurement from a wastewater application
point to a limiting layer.
   LAKE COUNTY. Lake County, Illinois.
   LIFT STATION. A watertight containment intended solely to collect pretreated
effluent and containing a submersible effluent pump, external pump switch(es),
an audio-visual alarm and additional pump control devices.
   LIMITING LAYER. That plane in a soil profile which restricts the placement
of a wastewater application point due to conditions including, but not limited
to, seasonal high water table or permanent saturated conditions, restrictive
permeability (loading rate of 0 gpd/sq.ft.), excessive permeability (gravelly
coarse sand or coarser texture), fractured bedrock, floodplain, frigipans,
bedrock, glacial tills, or natural depression areas, high water elevation of
any adjacent lake, pond, storm detention basin, stream, flood-prone area,
perched groundwater table, wetland, or other soil profile features that will
materially affect the absorption of liquid.
   LOADING RATE. The maximum rate, based upon a soil's texture, structure, and
consistence and expressed as gallons per day per square foot of infiltration
area, at which effluent may be applied to a soil absorption septic system.
   LOT. A portion of a platted land measured, set apart, and subdivided as a
distinct parcel having its principal frontage upon a street and created and
delineated upon a plat of subdivision or resubdivision and so recorded by the
Recorder of Deeds of Lake County, Illinois.
   MOTTLING. A Redoximorphic Feature of some soils which is associated with
high water tables, appearing as spotty patches of red, brown, orange and gray
colors and having a Munsell color chart chroma equal to or less than 2 and a
value equal to or greater than 4.
   NON-CONFORMING SYSTEM. A septic system intended for an atypical use or
application for which special consideration to flow, wastewater strength, or
wastewater disposal may result in special requirements which exceed the
standards set forth in this Chapter.
   PRE-TREATMENT UNIT. A septic tank, multiple septic tanks, a Class 1 Aerobic
Unit. (Note: The aerobic unit, including trash tanks, must be properly sized
for the projected daily wastewater volume and provide physical, chemical and
biological treatment to raw wastewater prior to its application to soil
infiltration.
   PRIMARY AREA. An area located in a site and designated for construction of
an Initial System leaching field.
   PRIMARY SYSTEM or INITIAL SYSTEM. The initial septic system constructed upon
a lot.
   PRIVATE INDIVIDUAL ONSITE SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM or SEPTIC SYSTEM. A Private
Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System is used to collect, treat, and
discharge or reclaim wastewater from an individual dwelling without the use of
community-wide or a centralized treatment facility. A conventional onsite
system includes a septic tank and a leaching field. Some of the other
alternative types of onsite systems include at-grade systems, mound systems,
sand filters and small aerobic units. The leaching field receives pretreated
wastewater and the soil further treats the wastewater by filtration, sorption,
and microbiological degradation before the water is discharged to ground water.
   REDOXIMORPHIC FEATURE. Soil characteristics associated with wetness which
result from the reduction and oxidation of iron and manganese compounds in the
soil, and are indicative of the extent of soil saturation.
   REPAIR. The replacement of or the addition or modification to an existing
Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System, which is continuing to serve
the same dwelling or structure, excluding maintenance activities such as
pumping the tanks, replacement of baffles or filter, replacement of
distribution boxes, replacement of electrical or mechanical components such as
pumps, switches, motors or controls.
   SANITARY SEWAGE AND/OR SANITARY WASTEWATER. A combination of the water-
carried human and other wastes from residences, business buildings, and other
habitable buildings and structures.
   SEPTAGE. Liquid and solid material removed from domestic septic tanks or
other approved pretreatment septic systems, and specifically excluding wastes
from portable toilets, holding tanks, grease traps and sewage treatment plant
sludge material.
   SITE. See BUILDABLE AREA.
   SITE DEVELOPMENT PLAN. A prepared plan which illustrates the final
contouring of a site, including modifications to the site associated with
proposed work on the Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System, to
specifications acceptable to the Village and the County of Lake.
   SOIL RESOURCE GROUP. A group of soils specific to this Chapter into five
types, I through V, based upon the extent of physical contact between seepage
trench or bed aggregate material and the natural soil.
   STORY. A division of a building extending horizontally at its base at the
same level and extending vertically at least seven feet (7') from the floor
surface to the underside of the ceiling, joists, or roof rafters lying directly
above it; provided that an attic shall not be considered a story, unless the
attic contains any plastered or dry-walled finished area, with or without
paneling or wood upon the surface thereof, having a minimum seven foot (7')
ceiling height; and further provided that, if the building contains a basement
as opposed to a cellar, the basement shall be considered a story; and, if the
building contains a cellar having two exterior walls whose base at the floor
level is at or above grade, such cellar shall be a story.
   TOPOGRAPHICAL SURVEY. A representation of changes in elevation of a property
prepared to scale by an Illinois licensed surveyor or engineer, which depicts
each 1 foot change in elevation by a contour line, is referenced to a benchmark
of known or assumed elevation, and which encompasses a sufficient area to
include the proposed structure, the Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal
System area and any other topographical feature relevant to the wastewater
septic system.
   VANITY. A dressing table or stand containing a wash basin.
   VILLAGE OF METTAWA or VILLAGE. The Village of Mettawa, Illinois, a home-rule
unit.
   VILLAGE ENGINEER. The Village Engineer of the Village or his designated
agent.
   WASTEWATER APPLICATION POINT. The point lowest in elevation at which
wastewater applied to a soil infiltration septic system will first contact with
soil or fill material.
   WETLAND. Land that is inundated or saturated by surface or shallow ground
water at a sufficient frequency and duration to support, under ordinary
conditions, a prevalence of vegetation adopted to such conditions (hydrophytic
vegetation).
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
   ARTICLE III. GENERAL REQUIREMENTS
SECTION 8.301. GENERAL.
   Authority. In order to protect and promote the health, safety, and general
welfare of the people of Lake County, Illinois, the Health Officer has
authorized and directed to develop procedures, practices and policies; to
interpret and enforce the rules and regulations of Lake County establishing
minimum standards for sewage discharges, the location, installation,
alteration, operation, maintenance, and monitoring of all Private Individual
Onsite Sewage Disposal Systems, so as to protect land, water, groundwater and
other natural resources within the County of Lake from impairment, pollution,
or destruction; to minimize the risk of spreading communicable diseases, and to
prevent and avoid other health and ecologic hazards attributable to bacteria,
viruses, protozoa and helminths, as well as, chemical contamination of lands
and waters. In addition, the Village of Mettawa hereby authorizes its Village
Engineer to enforce the rules and regulations of this Chapter establishing
minimum standards to further reduce the risk that Private Individual Onsite
Sewage Disposal Systems pose to the public health of the citizens of the
Village, so that Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal Systems:
   A.   Do not contaminate any potable water supply;
   B.   Are not accessible to insects, rodents, or other possible carriers of
disease which may come into contact with human food or drinking water;
   C.   Do not pollute or contaminate the water of any bathing beach or surface
waters used for public or domestic water supply or recreational purposes;
   D.   Do not give rise to a nuisance due to odor or unsightly appearance; and
   E.   Will not violate any other laws or regulations governing control of
water pollution or sewage disposal.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.302. RESTRICTIONS.
   A.   Water Conserving Plumbing Fixtures. Any building proposed to be
serviced by a Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System shall utilize
water conserving plumbing fixtures, including, but not limited to, low flush
volume toilets and flow restricting (2.5 gallons per minute) faucets and
showerheads. Whenever swimming pools and whirlpool tubs, spas, etc. with a
capacity exceeding 60 gallons are proposed to be installed upon the lot to be
served, the projected daily flow of the wastewater system shall be increased by
that capacity.
   B.   Property Boundaries. Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal Systems
shall not be located outside of the property boundaries of the serviced
dwelling or establishment, nor, unless specifically approved by the Village
Engineer, serve more than one dwelling or structure.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
   ARTICLE IV. UNSANITARY CONDITIONS
SECTION 8.401. GENERAL.
   A.   Discharge of Improperly Treated Sewage. Every Private Individual Onsite
Sewage Disposal System shall be maintained in proper sanitary condition and
repair by its owner. It shall be unlawful for any person to permit or cause the
discharge of improperly treated sewage directly or indirectly to a wetland,
surface waters, ground surface, well or abandoned well, or to allow the
contents of any sewage disposal system or components thereof, to emit offensive
odors or become objectionable so as to be dangerous or prejudicial to health.
   B.   Abatement Orders. Upon verification of such unsanitary condition, the
Village Engineer and/or the Building Official shall give or cause to be given a
written order of abatement to the owner and/or occupant responsible for such
acts or emissions. Failure of any person to obey such an abatement order shall
also constitute a separate violation of this Chapter. Lake County regulations
shall apply to any person receiving an abatement order from the Health Officer.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
   ARTICLE V. APPROVAL PROCEDURES
SECTION 8.501. CONSTRUCTION, MODIFICATION AND/OR REPAIR.
   No person shall construct, modify or repair a Private Individual Onsite
Sewage Disposal System without the prior approval of the Health Officer and the
Village Engineer. Such approval shall include both the approval of a plan for
the proposed construction or repair, and the issuance of a permit by the
Building Official to conduct the work required.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.502. NEW CONSTRUCTION APPROVAL CONDITIONS.
   The Village Engineer shall review and approve of the location for new
Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal Systems. After the Village Engineer’s
review and approval of the location, provided the Lake County Health Department
has approved the plans and specifications for a new Private Individual Onsite
Sewage Disposal System, the Village Engineer shall approve said plans and
specifications.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003; Am. Ord. 746,
passed 12-17-2013)
SECTION 8.503. REPAIR, MODIFICATION OR REPLACEMENT.
   A.   Approval Conditions. Provided the Village Engineer has first approved
the location for, and then the Lake County Health Department then has approved
the plans and specifications for, the repair, modification or replacement of a
Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System, the Village Engineer shall
approve said plans and specifications.
   B.   Compliance Impossible. If there is no expansion area with undisturbed
suitable soils for a replacement field, a repair of an existing failing septic
system may be approved when the septic system cannot meet the criteria for
flow, setbacks, number of soil borings and loading rates as assigned by the
soil evaluation report, but the proposal is in substantial compliance with
these criteria so as to reasonably meet the requirements for wastewater
disposal and to be in the best interest of public health. The repair plans must
also meet all requirements and approvals of the Lake County Health Department
and/or The Illinois Department of Public Health. The Lake County Health
Department and/or the Village Engineer may place restrictions upon the use of
the septic system to reduce flow to minimize the risk of septic system failure.
Such restrictions shall be made covenant(s) running with the land and shall be
filed with the Lake County Recorder of Deeds for recordation against the title
to the lot containing the septic system. The Building Official shall not
approve plans for alterations or additions to existing buildings or other
structures unless proposed modifications to an existing septic system or a new
septic system meet all of the requirements of this Municipal Code.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003; Am. Ord. 515,
passed 4-20-2004; Am. Ord. 746, passed 12-17-2013)
SECTION 8.504. APPROVAL CONDITIONS -- ALTERATIONS OR ADDITIONS.
   No dwelling or establishment served by a Private Individual Onsite Sewage
Disposal System may be altered, expanded, remodeled, or added to where such
change may affect the Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System without
prior approval of the Lake County Health Department and the Village Engineer.
Applications for building additions or structural building alterations shall be
made to the Building Official and plans and specifications therefor shall be
reviewed by the Village Engineer but not approved unless the Lake County Health
Department has given approval.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003; Am. Ord. 746,
passed 12-17-2013)
SECTION 8.505. NON-CONFORMING SYSTEMS PROHIBITED.
   The Village Engineer shall not approve plans and specifications for a
proposed Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System which do not meet the
requirements of this Chapter and the Building Official shall not issue any
permit for the lot without plans approved by the Village Engineer.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.506. APPROVAL CONDITIONS - PROPOSED SUBDIVISION.
   Where Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal Systems are to be used for
any subdivision or resubdivision of any subdivision, tract, parcel or lot of
land into two or more parts of mapping, platting, conveyance, change or
rearrangement of boundaries, the Village Engineer shall review each lot to
ensure it will have a minimum 30,000 square foot area in the buildable area
which is suitable for a Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System and
its required expansion area. No subdivision shall be approved unless all final
lots are considered suitable for a Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal
System as follows:
   A.   Site Suitability. The suitability of proposed subdivision stress
utilizing individual soil absorption sewage disposal systems shall be
determined by the results of the soil evaluations that are conducted in
accordance with Article VI and by the platting of proposed lots with Article
IX.
   B.   Natural Resource Protection. The subdivision shall be designed to
protect all natural resources such as drainage ways, wetlands, wooded areas,
surface waters, and soil conditions. Such information shall be provided by a
registered Professional Engineer licensed to practice in the State of Illinois
in accordance with Section 8.905.
   C.   Expansion Areas. Every lot served by a Private Individual Onsite Sewage
Disposal System shall have a minimum 30,000 square foot area of suitable soil
located in the buildable area for sewage disposal sufficient for both a primary
system and an expansion system, relative to soil conditions and system design.
A review shall be made of the preliminary plat of subdivision and the soil
borings and lot lines shall be adjusted to eliminate any unsuitable lots. In
all cases an Expansion System must be constructed on the site upon the failure
of the Primary System and/or the construction of a guest house or additional
bedrooms on the lot.
   D.   Area Protection. All designated Private Individual Onsite Sewage
Disposal System areas must be protected from damage before and during the
construction of the roads, utilities, drainage, etc., in the subdivision. Snow
fencing, two by fours or equivalent shall be placed so as to protect wastewater
disposal areas.
   E.   Before a new subdivision is approved, each proposed lot must be
identified on a topographical survey. Land suitable for site must be identified
by soil testing and shown on the topographical survey. Until a system is
constructed, this site must then be protected from any construction or other
activity that would lessen its suitability for a septic leaching field.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.507. VARIANCE REQUESTS.
   Whenever approval as required by this Article is denied by the Village
Engineer, and where compliance with the requirements of this Chapter is
impossible or impractical, that person denied approval may request a variance.
The Zoning Board of Appeals shall hear and make recommendations to the
President and Board of Trustees on all requests for variations from the
regulations contained in this Article. Variation requests shall be applied for
and processed in accordance with the provisions of Article VIII (Variations) of
Chapter 15 of this Code.
   A.   Supporting Data. Variance requests shall include pertinent data to
support the requested waiver of the requirements of this Chapter as being
consistent with the responsibility of the Village Engineer to protect and
provide for the health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of the
Village.
   B.   Zoning Board of Appeals. Provided the Lake County Health Officer has
given approval of the plans and specifications for the proposed Private
Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System, whenever the Village Clerk is in
receipt of a written application for a variance with supporting data, the
Village Clerk shall forward the application to the Village Engineer.
   C.   Review by the Zoning Board of Appeals. Except as otherwise set forth
herein, the Zoning Board of Appeals shall have jurisdiction to hear and make
recommendations to the President and Board of Trustees for variations from the
provisions of this Chapter. In making its recommendation, the Zoning Board of
Appeals shall have the right to rely on advice provided it by the Village
Engineer and the Village's Septic System consultant engineer. A majority vote
of the members of the Zoning Board of Appeals shall be required to make a
recommendation to grant or deny a request for variation from the provisions of
this Chapter.
   D.   Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this Section, the Village
Engineer is authorized hereby to modify the minimum 30,000 square foot
Buildable Area to 20,000 square feet, when he is in receipt of proof of
recordation against the title to the Lot in question of a restrictive covenant
containing the written approval of the Village President and Board of Trustees
and forbidding the erection or construction upon such Lot of a guest house or
building containing servants' or caretakers' quarters.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003; Am. Ord. 548,
passed 10-18-2005)
   ARTICLE VI. SITE SUITABILITY
SECTION 8.601. SOIL EVALUATION.
   A.   General. All proposed Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal Systems
shall be designed based upon soil characteristics as identified by the Lake
County Health Officer employed Soil Scientist or Lake County licensed Soil
Classifier, and as recorded on a soil evaluation report.
   B.   Proposed Subdivision. New, proposed subdivisions, where Private
Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal Systems are proposed, shall be designed based
upon soil characteristics as identified by a Lake County Health Officer
employed Soil Scientist or a Lake County licensed Soil Classifier.
   C.   Soil Evaluation. The person requesting the soil evaluation shall
undertake the following:
      1.   Clearing the proposed leaching field of the site without running
equipment on any parts of a site which are wet or damp.
      2.   Staking the buildable area corners as well as the front, side and
rear zoning yards.
      3.   Excavating soil observation pits twenty-four inches (24") wide to a
minimum depth of sixty inches (60").
      4.   Providing soil cores meeting standards engineering practice, which
the Village Engineer may accept as meeting the requirements of this Section to
allow a judgment to be made as to soil conditions at the site.
   D.   Minimum Number of Observation Points. Soil observation points shall be
located as is necessary to accurately determine the soil characteristics of the
site, however, a minimum number of observation points shall be provided as
follows:
      1.   Individual Sites. On individual sites, a minimum of eight (8)
observation points are required in the buildable area with at least one point
located in a buildable area lower in elevation than any proposed soil
absorption septic system or expansion areas.
      2.   Proposes Subdivisions. The site located on the buildable area of
each proposed lot in a new or proposed subdivision shall be tested as provided
above for individual sites.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.602. SOIL DESCRIPTIONS.
   A.   General. Soil characteristics shall be described based upon United
States Department of Agriculture Natural Resources Conservation Service
(formerly the Soil Conservation Service) National Standards. Descriptions shall
include depth in inches to changes in soil texture, soil structure, soil
consistence and/or compaction, observed saturation, soil coloration, and depth
to redosimorphic features indicative of saturation including, but not limited
to, common (2% - 20%) low chroma mottles (equal to or less than two (2) and a
value of four (4) or more based upon Munsell color chart). Descriptions shall
be recorded to a depth of 60 inches.
   B.   Additional Determination and Assignments. In addition to the standard
soil description in paragraph A of this Section, the following determinations
and assignments made by the Lake County Health Officer employed Soil Scientist
or Lake County Licensed Soil Classifier shall apply:
      1.    Soil Resource Group. Each observation point soil profile is
classified in accordance with Appendix B to establish a soil resource group,
soil series or classification, the depth to a limiting layer and the
corresponding minimum Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System type.
Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System types relate to the depth to a
limiting layer, and establish a required minimum separation distance between
the limiting layer and a wastewater application point of 24 inches.
      2.   Wastewater Loading Rates. Each soil description assigns maximum
wastewater loading rates in accordance with Appendix B, as follows:
         a.   Soil descriptions are segregated by horizon.
         b.   Each segregated horizon is assigned a loading rate between 0
gallons per day per square foot (gpd/sq.ft.) and .8 gpd/sq.ft.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.603. MINIMUM SOIL CONDITIONS.
   A.   Soil Suitability. At a minimum, any soil located in a proposed soil
absorption or expansion area must be described in the soil evaluation as having
twelve inches (12") of suitable soil at the surface, meeting all of the
following conditions:
      1.    The soil is not seasonally saturated to within twelve inches (12")
of the surface; and when classified per Section
8.602B1 and Appendix B specifies a Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal
System type.
      2.   Soil texture, structure, and consistence are such that the loading
rate, assigned per Section
8.602B2 and Appendix B is greater than zero (0) gpd/sq.ft.
      3.   The soil evaluation is not over two years old, unless updated by the
soil scientist who provided the original evaluation.
   B.   Made Land Soils. Soils which are not naturally occurring, having been
filled over, cut or otherwise disturbed so as to make their classification
impossible to impracticable, may be considered as suitable where the depth to
seasonal saturation and the soil texture, soil structure, and soil consistence
meet the criteria for suitable soil established in this Section. A more
extensive soil investigation may be necessary to determine the suitability
thereof. The Lake County Health Department employed Soil Scientist or a Lake
County licensed Soil Classifier assigns a Private Individual Onsite Sewage
Disposal System type and loading rates in accordance with Appendix B, which
assignment shall apply.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.604. ACCEPTABLE SOIL EVALUATIONS OF RECORD.
   Soil evaluations conducted prior to the effective date of this Chapter may
be acceptable as meeting the purpose of this Article, provided the evaluation
was conducted by a Lake County Health Village Engineer employed Soil Scientist,
and the soil profile description is sufficient to allow a translation of
information by a Lake County Health Department employed Soil Scientist to
Appendix B for a determination of soil suitability.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.605. CONFLICT RESOLUTION.
   Whenever there is a substantial disagreement between the Lake County Health
Department and any Lake County Licensed Soil Classifier, the Village Engineer
shall solicit the assistance of the Natural Resources Conservation Service Area
soil scientist to resolve such disputes. The report of the natural Resource
Conservation Service shall be considered as the soil evaluation of record.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.606. PROCEDURES AND FEES.
   Administrative procedure and fees relative to this Chapter shall be as set
forth in Chapter 2, Village Government, Article X, Tax, Fee, Fine and Penalty
Schedules, Section
2.1002, Fee Schedule.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003; Am. Ord. 852,
passed 10-20-2020)
   ARTICLE VII. PRIVATE SANITARY SEWAGE SEPTIC SYSTEM DESIGN
SECTION 8.701. GENERAL PURPOSE.
   Each Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System and its required
expansion area proposed for approval shall meet the following minimum design
requirements:
   A.   System Capacity. To ensure that Private Individual Onsite Sewage
Disposal Systems are of an adequate capacity to dispose of the projected
wastewater volume. (See also Subsection J of this Section)
   B.   Suitable Soil. The sanitary sewage septic soil absorption system and
its required expansion area shall be located in suitable soil in accordance
with Section
8.603.
   C.   System Type. The sanitary sewage septic soil absorption system and its
required expansion shall be of a Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal
System type as specified by Section
8.602 and Appendix B, and the design for that Private Individual Onsite Sewage
Disposal System type shall conform to the requirements of this Section and any
applicable elements of materials incorporated by Appendix A.
   D.   Site Contour. The sanitary sewage septic soil absorption system and its
required expansion area shall be designed to be parallel to the site contour.
Soil absorption systems shall not be situated on slopes which are concave to
the extent that horizontal subsurface movement of wastewater may concentrate
that flow in a small downslope area.
   E.   Sizing. All components of a Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal
System and the soil absorption area shall be properly sized for the wastewater
flow projected by Appendix C in accordance with all other applicable
requirements of this Section. (See also Subsection J of this Section)
   F.   Horizontal Separation Distances. Each Private Individual Onsite Sewage
Disposal System shall be located within the buildable area and shall be
separated from water wells and water supply lines, surface waters,
topographical features, artificial drains, property lines and easements, and
construction elements by a distance set forth in the definition of "Buildable
Area" and Appendix D, whichever is the most restrictive, being adequate to
protect the system from any damage or interference with the treatment and
disposal process, and to ensure that untreated wastewater does not contaminate
drinking waters, surface waters, or the ground surface, in accordance with
Appendix D.
   G.   Prohibited Wastes. Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal Systems
shall be designed to receive only domestic sewage. No discharges from footing
drains, water softeners, air conditioning, or other clear water source, nor
greases, oils, solvents or other waste except domestic sewage shall be
discharged into an Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System.
   H.   Construction and Materials. Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal
Systems shall be designed to allow their construction in accordance with
Article X of this Chapter and shall specify approved materials in accordance
with Article XI.
   I.   (Intentionally omitted.)
   J.   Additional Design Requirements. Private Individual Onsite Sewage
Disposal Systems types shall be designed in accordance with the requirements of
this Section, and with the design requirements further specified in the
incorporated materials of Appendix A for the specific septic system type
wherever not otherwise specified. Septic systems to be constructed in the
Village of Mettawa shall be designed for a single family residence having a
garbage grinder and a minimum of six bedrooms.
   K.   Design Requirements Specific to Private Individual Onsite Sewage
Disposal System types. Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System types
shall be particularly designed as follows:
      1.   Type 1 and Type 2 Absorption Trench Systems. Type 1 and 2 absorption
trench systems shall be designed to minimum requirements as follows:
         a.   Pretreatment shall be by septic tank sized for the projected
design flow per Appendix C. A cartridge type effluent filter shall be required,
and placed in an easily accessible separate compartment located down line
following the last treatment tank and before the lift station, if any.
         b.   Distribution to the absorption trench may be by dropbox, serial
distribution, or by equal flow distribution box. Piping and distribution device
size and material shall comply with Article XI.
         c.   Lift stations, if required, shall be sized according to Appendix
C.
         d.   Distribution into the absorption trench shall be by perforated
pipe.
         e.   No perforation shall be located closer than three feet to the
proximate end of the absorption trench.
         f.   No perforation shall be located closer than three feet to the
proximal end of the absorption trench.
         g.   The invert of the distribution pipe shall be a minimum of six (6)
inches above the trench bottom.
         h.   The area of trench bottom area shall be equal to the projected
flow in gallons per day (gpd) divided by the assigned wastewater loading rate
in gallons per day per square foot.
         i.   (Intentionally omitted.)
         j.   The maximum trench length shall be one hundred (100) feet from
the distribution device. All trenches connected to an equal flow distribution
box shall be of equal length.
         k.   The maximum trench width shall be thirty-six (36) inches; the
minimum trench width shall be twelve (12) inches.
         l.   Trenches shall be separated by a minimum of four (4) feet of
undisturbed soil.
         m.   The maximum trench depth for a Type 1 system shall be eighteen
(18) inches into the original soil or otherwise deeper as approved provided
that the required vertical isolation distance is maintained.
         n.   The maximum trench depth for a Type 2 system shall be twelve (12)
inches into the original soil.
         o.   The minimum depth of gravel in the absorption trench shall be
twelve (12) inches, with six (6) inches of gravel beneath the distribution pipe
and two (2) inches above. Gravel shall not be placed closer than twenty-four
(24) inches to the distribution device.
         p.   Every Type 2 system shall be covered with a minimum of six (6)
inches of topsoil or otherwise as is necessary to support vegetative cover with
a maximum cover of eighteen (18) inches.
         q.   Where distribution to and into a Type 1 or 2 system is by low
pressure pipe, the applicable requirements of Section 8.702.
         r.   Seepage beds, if proposed, shall be sized at 1.5 times the trench
absorption area.
         s.   Leaching chambers, if proposed, shall be sized according to the
area of the trench bottom relative to the width of the chamber.
      2.   Type 4 At-Grade Absorption Systems. Type 4 At-Grade Absorption
Systems shall be designed to minimum requirements as follows:
         a.   Pretreatment shall be by septic tank sized for the projected flow
per Appendix C and by a Class 1 aerobic unit sized for the projected flow per
Appendix C. A cartridge type effluent filter shall be required, and placed in
an easily accessible separate compartment located down line following the last
treatment tank and before the lift station, if any.
         b.   The soil absorption area shall be plowed in accordance with
Section
8.1007.
         c.   Distribution to and into the absorption area shall be by low
pressure pipe (LPP). LPP network piping shall be as specified in this Section
and in Section
8.702.
         d.   The lift station shall be sized according to Appendix C.
         e.   The invert of the distribution lines shall be a minimum of six
(6) inches above original grade.
         f.   The area of absorption area shall be equal to the projected daily
flow in gallons per day divided by the assigned wastewater loading rate in
gallons per day per square foot.
         g.   The minimum length of the at-grade wastewater absorption area
parallel to the site contour shall be limited by the maximum linear loading
rate. The linear loading rate is equal to the projected daily flow in gallons
per day divided by the total length of the absorption area in feet, and shall
be limited as follows:
            1)   Type 4 systems on soils in resource groups A, B or C shall be
designed with a maximum linear loading rate of twelve (12) gallons per day per
foot.
            2)   Type 4 systems on soils in resource groups D or E shall be
designed with a maximum linear loading rate of six (6) gallons per day per
foot.
         h.   The minimum depth of gravel in the at-grade absorption area shall
be ten (10) inches, with six (6) inches of gravel beneath the pipe and two (2)
inches above.
         i.   (Intentionally omitted.)
         j.   The gravel of an at-grade soil absorption system shall be covered
with a minimum of twelve (12) inches of topsoil to support vegetative cover.
Additional cover shall be placed as is necessary to shed stormwater.
         k.   The gravel shall be completely covered with an appropriate
geotextile prior to the placement of topsoil.
         l.   Type 4 At-Grade systems shall comply with the provisions of the
Wisconsin At-Grade Soil Absorption System Siting, Design and Construction
Manual as incorporated in Appendix A.
      3.   Type 5 Mound Systems. Type 5 Mound Systems shall be designed to
minimum requirements as follows:
         a.   Pretreatment shall be by septic tank sized for the projected flow
per Appendix C and by a Class I aerobic unit sized for the projected flow per
Appendix C. A cartridge type effluent filter shall be required, and placed in
an easily accessible separate compartment located down line following the last
treatment tank and before the lift station, if any.
         b.   The soil infiltration area shall be plowed and filled in
accordance with Section 8.1003 and Section 8.1004. The fill material shall
cover the soil infiltration area, or basal area.
         c.   Distribution to and into the application bed shall be by low
pressure pipe (LPP). LPP network piping shall be as specified in this Section
and in Section 8.704.
         d.   The lift station shall be sized according to Appendix C.
         e.   The invert of the distribution line(s) shall be a minimum of six
(6) inches above the fill material.
         f.   The area of the application bed (absorption area) shall be equal
to the projected daily flow in gallons per day divided by the loading rate of
the coarse sand fill, one gallons per day per square foot (1 gpd/sq.ft.) or 1.2
gpd/sq.ft. where an aerobic unit is proposed for pretreatment.
         g.   The minimum length of the application bed parallel to the site
contour shall be limited by the maximum linear loading rate. The linear loading
rate is equal to the projected daily flow in gallons per day divided by the
total length of the application bed in feet, and shall be limited as follows:
            1)   Type 5 systems on soils in resource groups A, B or C shall be
designed with a maximum linear loading rate of eight (8) gallons per day per
foot.
            2)   Type 5 systems on soils in resource groups D or E shall be
designed with a maximum linear loading rate of four (4) gallons per day per
foot.
         h.   The area of the infiltration area (basal area) shall be equal to
the projected daily flow divided by the assigned soil wastewater loading rate
in gallons per day per square foot.
         i.   (Intentionally omitted.)
         j.   The basal area is defined, based upon the slope of the site,
illustrated in Appendix E.
         k.   The minimum length of the basal area shall be equal to the
minimum length of the application bed, per Section 8.703B3g.
         l.   The fill material shall be extended beyond the basal area,
tapering to grade at 3:1 slope.
         m.   The minimum depth of gravel in the application bed shall be ten
(10) inches of gravel beneath the pipe and two (2) inches above.
         n.   The minimum depth of coarse sand fill material covering the basal
area shall be twelve (12) inches.
         o.   The entire Type 5 Mound System shall be covered with a minimum of
twelve (12) inches of topsoil to support vegetative cover. Additional cover
shall be placed over the application bed at a slope in order to shed
stormwater.
         p.   The gravel of the application bed shall be completely covered
with an appropriate geotextile prior to the placement of topsoil.
         q.   Type 5 Mound systems shall comply with the provisions of
Wisconsin Mound Soil Absorption System Siting, Design and Construction Manual
as incorporated in Appendix A.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.702. LOW PRESSURE DISTRIBUTION.
   Low Pressure Pipe Systems: Distribution of wastewater into Private
Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal Systems by low pressure pipe (LPP) systems as
required by this section shall be designed to minimum requirements, as follows:
   A.   Pretreatment of effluent shall include an approved effluent filter for
septic tank effluent or a Class I aerobic unit, as prescribed by Section
8.701.
   B.   Minimum supply/manifold line diameter shall be two (2) inches.
   C.   Minimum lateral wastewater distribution pipe diameter shall be one and
one-quarter (1-1/4) inches.
   D.   Minimum perforation size shall be three-sixteenths (3/16) inches.
   E.   Maximum perforation spacing shall be six (6) feet.
   F.   Minimum distal end pressure on any lateral line shall be one (1) foot
of pressure head (.43 psi).
   G.   Maximum distal end pressure on any lateral line shall be five (5) feet
of pressure head (2.16 psi).
   H.   The discharge rate of distribution lines shall be a minimum of .15
gallons per minute per lineal foot, and shall be equal among all distribution
lines to within plus or minus five (5) percent.
   I.   (intentionally omitted.)
   J.   Construction shall comply with the requirements of Article IX, and all
materials shall comply with the requirements of Article X.
   K.   Low pressure pipe distribution systems shall otherwise comply with the
requirements of Design and Installation of Low Pressure Pipe Waste Treatment
Systems as incorporated by Appendix A.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
   ARTICLE VIII. PRIVATE SANITARY SEWAGE SEPTIC SYSTEM PLANS
SECTION 8.801. PLANS REQUIRED.
   Prior to granting approval for a Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal
System, the person seeking approval shall submit to the Health Officer and the
Village Engineer a plan prepared according to the terms of this Article in
order to demonstrate compliance of the proposed Private Individual Onsite
Sewage Disposal System with the requirements of this Chapter.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.802. PLAN SPECIFICATIONS.
   Whether the proposal is to construct a new system or only to repair, replace
or add septic tanks, lift stations, pre-treatment units or other components or
to construct a new system, a plan for a Private Individual Onsite Sewage
Disposal System shall meet the minimum standards established in this section.
In the case of proposed or new subdivisions, the plan must demonstrate
compliance with regard to each lot in the subdivision and the capacity of each
lot to meet the requirements of this Chapter.
   A.   Minimum Plan Standards:
      1.   The Plan shall be prepared by a Registered Professional Engineer who
is also licensed as a Lake County individual Sewage 1 Disposal System Designer.
      2.    The Plan shall be drawn to a scale of 1" = 10', 1" = 20' or 1" =
30' on a readable topographical survey presented on sheets measuring at least
twenty-four inches by thirty-six inches (24" x 36") with a location map,
showing a sketch of the location of the lot and containing a legal description
of the lot.
   B.   Plan Formulation Requirements: The plan shall show and specify
dimensions for:
      •   All property lines;
      •   The buildable area;
      •   All existing and proposed buildings, driveways and other
improvements;
      •   All utility easements, underground utility and services lines, and
any overhead utility lines within twenty-five feet (25') of the proposed well
location;
      •   All existing and proposed water wells on the lot or within seventy-
five feet (75') of a lot line, demonstrating the entire radius of any proposed
or existing well on the lot;
      •   The existing and/or proposed site of the Private Individual Onsite
Sewage Disposal System on the lot as well as the existing and/or proposed site
of a Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System within seventy-five feet
(75') of a properly line of the lot;
      •   All drainage easements, ditches, streams, swales or other stormwater
pathways, including storm sewers and stormwater management facilities such as
detention and retention basins;
      •   A delineation of all surface waters and wetlands on the lot or within
fifty feet (50') of a property line of the lot;
      •   Proposed roadways and other areas where existing soils will be
disturbed;
      •   Heavily wooded areas or required conservancies; and
      •   Proposed grading of the site.
   C.   Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System Specifications:
      1.   Location and size of all Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal
System components, including septic tanks, pretreatment units, lift stations,
and:
         a.   Piping to the soil absorption system;
         b.   Distribution boxes, drop boxes, diverter valves;
         c.   Soil absorption trenches;
         d.   Pressure distribution piping in at-grade or mound systems;
         e.   Gravel application beds in mound systems; and
         f.   Areas of approved filling.
      2.   The location of all soil evaluation points; and
      3.   The location for material storage and a pathway for construction
traffic.
   D.   Specific Elevations:
      1.   The elevation of a permanent benchmark;
      2.   The elevation of floodplain, if any;
      3.   The elevations of the invert of the building sewer and the inlet(s)
of the septic tank or other pretreatment units;
      4.   The elevation of the invert of a distribution box, except where a
lift station is proposed; and
      5.   The elevation of any low pressure lateral distribution line.
   E.   A detailed cross section for the soil absorption system specifying
original grade and the relative placement of fill material, gravel, piping and
cover material.
   F.   The soil evaluation report accompanied by soil maps and soil boring
logs.
   G.   A calculation of the projected wastewater daily flow, including a floor
plan of a proposed residence or establishment.
   H.   A calculation of the capacity of the components of the system and of
the soil absorption system.
   I.   (Intentionally omitted.)
   J.   A calculation of the bed length of an at-grade or mound system as
referenced in Section
8.701.
   K.   A calculation of low pressure pipe distribution system as referenced in
Section
8.702.
   L.   Reports from engineers, wetland consultants, or other professionals, as
may be required to establish stormwater drainage, wetland delineations, surface
water elevations, floodplain or other applicable information necessary for the
evaluation of the plan.
   M.   An approved site development plan, pursuant to Section
8.502.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003; Am. Ord. 515,
passed 4-2004)
   ARTICLE IX. CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS
SECTION 8.901. GENERAL.
   A.   Every Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System, once approved,
shall be constructed in a manner to preserve the condition of the soil
absorption area, and to promote the long-term sanitary treatment and disposal
of wastewater.
   B.   In addition to inspections performed by the Health Officer, the Village
Engineer shall conduct inspections of Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal
Systems under construction to ensure compliance with the requirements of this
Chapter.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.902. PERMIT AND LICENSE REQUIREMENTS.
   A.   Construction Permit: No Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal
System shall be constructed or repaired until a permit for its construction or
repair has been issued. An approved construction permit shall be posted on the
site in a prominent location.
      1.   Site Evaluation: The Village Engineer shall evaluate each site prior
to the issuance of the construction permit by the Building Official to ensure
that the soil absorption area has not been altered, that the soil absorption
area is protected by fencing, and that the information previously submitted and
approved is substantially unchanged.
      2.   Right to Stop Construction: Where the conditions on the site are
inconsistent with the approved plan, or where the soil absorption area is
unprotected from construction traffic by appropriate fencing, construction of
the system may be stopped by either the Health Officer or the Village Engineer.
Where the issuance of a construction permit is refused, the Village Engineer
and/or the Building Official may require corrective action or an initiation of
the original approval process as appropriate.
   B.   Licensed Contractor: No person shall construct or repair a Private
Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System in Lake County unless such person
holds a valid Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System Contractor's
License issued by the County of Lake. The licensed contractor shall directly
supervise all work conducted on an Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal
System, and shall be responsible to ensure that the work complies with this
Chapter.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.903. SITE PREPARATION.
   A.   Preparation of the soil absorption area shall be conducted only when
the soil is dry. Site preparation shall be conducted under the supervision of
the licensed contractor.
   B.   All sites shall be mowed and cleared of brush.
   C.   Removal of trees shall be by cutting near the surface. Stumps may be
removed by grinding or cutting, but shall not be uprooted.
   D.   Sites approved for Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System
Types 4 and 5 shall be plowed prior to the placement of fill or gravel as
follows:
      1.   Equipment shall be a chiselplow or mold board plow.
      2.   Plowing shall be done parallel to the site contour.
      3.   Tillage shall be minimal to break the consistency of the sod;
maximum depth of tilling shall be eight inches (8").
      4.   After tilling, the site shall not be graded or smoothed.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.904. FILL.
   The placement of fill material for Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal
System Types 4 and 5 shall be as established in this section.
   A.   Fill shall be approved coarse sand, except in the Type 4 at-grade
system where only gravel is required, but is handled and placed in the same
manner as fill material.
   B.   The fill shall be placed according to the approved plan and shall be
placed immediately after site preparation.
   C.   The storage and transportation of fill shall be as specified on the
approved plan; no traffic shall be allowed directly on the plowed area.
   D.   Fill shall be placed only from the upslope or ends of the proposed soil
absorption area as follows:
      1.   Using Backhoe: Material may be placed with a backhoe reaching into
the soil absorption area.
      2.   Using Low Compression Equipment: Material may be pushed into the
soil absorption area by low compression equipment maintaining a minimum of ten
inches of material beneath the equipment.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.905. EXCAVATION.
   The excavation for components and soil absorption trenches shall be as
established by this section.
   A.   Excavations for septic tanks, pretreatment units, lift stations, sewer
lines, header lines, pressure supply lines and other system components other
than soil absorption trenches shall be as follows:
      1.   Appropriate Elevations or Overcut: Excavations shall be made to the
appropriate elevation or overcut only to accommodate bedding material.
      2.   Grading: Excavations shall be level or uniformly graded as
appropriate so that tanks, containers, and piping is supported and secure.
      3.   Slope Excavations for piping shall be uniformly sloped so that
wastewater does not pond in bowed areas.
   B.   Excavation for soil absorption trenches or beds shall be as follows:
      1.   Site Contour: Excavation shall be uniformly along the site contour,
not exceeding the depth specified on the approved plan.
      2.   Bottom Surface: The trench or bed shall be excavated with a level
bottom surface.
      3.   Compaction and/or Smearing Protection: Excavation shall be done so
as to preserve the infiltrative trench or bed bottom and side walls from
compaction and/or smearing.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.906. GRAVEL.
   Gravel shall be placed in soil absorption trenches as follows:
   A.   The depth of gravel specified below the distribution pipe shall be
uniform, and of the minimum depth established in this Chapter.
   B.   The gravel shall be placed carefully to avoid compaction of the
infiltrative surface.
   C.   Gravel shall be placed around the distribution piping and covering the
piping a minimum of two inches (2").
   D.   The top of gravel in any soil absorption system shall be covered with
geotextile prior to backfilling. Other approved barrier materials, such as
untreated building paper or straw, may be employed except where geotextile is
specifically required.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.907. PIPING.
   All piping installed in Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal Systems
shall be uniformly supported, sloped as appropriate, and otherwise installed as
established in this section.
   A.   Building sewers shall be sloped not less than one-eighth (1/8) inch per
foot nor more than one-quarter (1/4) inch per foot.
   B.   Piping shall be connected, solvent joined, or attached with an
appropriate adapter as acceptable for the material to ensure that connections
do not separate or allow the leakage of wastewater or infiltration of
groundwater.
   C.   Piping entering or exiting septic tanks, pretreatment units, lift
stations, distribution devices, or other component not equipped with a
watertight connection shall be sealed.
   D.   Pipe connectors and fittings on pressure supply lines, manifolds, or
lateral distribution pipes shall be pressure connectors or fittings.
   E.   Pipe directly connected to distribution boxes shall be rigid, non-
corrugated, non-perforated pipe extending into the absorption area as specified
by this Chapter.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.908. BACKFILLING.
   Backfilling operations shall be conducted as established in this Section.
   A.   Backfill material shall meet the specifications established by Section
8.1108.
   B.   Backfill material shall not be frozen or wet.
   C.   Backfilling and covering shall be completed as soon as practical.
However, no Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System or part thereof
shall be backfilled until the system has been inspected and approved by the
Village Engineer. Any part that has been covered before inspection and approval
shall be uncovered as required by the Village Engineer.
   D.   Backfilling and covering shall direct stormwater to drain away from
system components and the soil absorption area.
   E.   Backfill for excavations of tanks, distribution devices, piping, etc.,
shall be carefully placed to avoid displacing the components. The backfill
material shall be tamped or compacted to secure the components, minimize
settling, and prevent wastewater seepage along excavations.
   F.   Backfill and/or cover for soil absorption areas shall be carefully
placed to avoid displacing the barrier material.
   G.   The backfill or cover shall be placed with a minimum of equipment
traffic.
   H.   No traffic shall be allowed on downslope areas or expansion areas.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.909. ACCESSORIES.
   Devices and piping employed for the distribution of wastewater into the soil
absorption area or regulating the flow of wastewater shall be constructed,
installed or equipped as established by this Section.
   A.   Where an equal flow distribution box is employed to direct wastewater
flow to two or more wastewater absorption pipes, the invert elevation of all
outflow pipes shall be leveled with a premanufactured cap specifically designed
to adjust the flowline of distribution box piping.
   B.   Perforations drilled into low pressure pipe wastewater distribution
lines shall be carefully placed along a straight line, and drilled at a
perpendicular angle to the apex of the pipe.
   C.   Diversion valves, flow control valves, effluent filters or any other
component which is located outside of a septic tank or similar containment
shall be provided with access to final grade sufficient to allow applicable
adjustment or maintenance as required.
   D.   Lift station pumps shall be placed at least six inches (6") above the
floor of the lift station. Float switches shall be secured to the vertical
piping with corrosion resistant straps or ties. All pumps shall be provided
with a threaded coupling or other disconnecting fitting, and shall be provided
with a corrosion resistant rope, strap or other device for removing the pump.
   E.   Pumps, aerobic units, or other mechanical system shall be provided with
an audio-visual alarm. Electrical wiring and connections shall conform to
applicable standards.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.910. COMPLIANCE.
   A.   In addition to the Health Officer, the Village Engineer shall make
inspections of the construction of Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal
Systems to ensure compliance with the requirements of this Chapter.
   B.   Required Inspections: Inspections shall be requested by the licensed
contractor as follows:
      1.   Site Preparation: Inspection of the plowed surface of the soil
absorption area.
      2.   System: Inspection of completed system prior to backfill or cover,
of low pressure pipe prior to gravel cover, and other components as necessary.
      3.    Final: Inspection of final grading, pressure tests of low pressure
systems, floor plan, clean water discharges, system accessories, and other
items as necessary. Following its construction and installation on a lot, no
Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System or part thereof shall be
backfilled until the system has been inspected and approved by the Village
Engineer and the Health Officer. Any part that has been covered before
inspection and approval shall be uncovered as required by the Village Engineer.
      4.    Nonconforming System Parts: Where inspection discloses defective
material or unworkmanlike construction which does not conform to the
requirements of this Chapter, the nonconforming parts shall be removed,
replaced and reinspected.
      5.   Other Inspections: The Village Engineer may require or conduct any
other inspections as in his judgement may be necessary.
      6.    Final Approval: No Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System
shall be placed into service without a final inspection by, and the final
approval of, the Village Engineer and the Health Officer.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
   ARTICLE X. MATERIALS
SECTION 8.1001. GENERAL.
   A.   Minimum Standards: Specifications detailed in this Article shall be
deemed minimum.
      1.   All materials employed in the construction or repair of Private
Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal Systems shall be to the specifications of
this Chapter to minimize maintenance, repair, or replacement and to promote the
long-term treatment and disposal of wastewater.
      2.   All materials, equipment and devices approved for use shall be
constructed and installed in accordance with such approval.
   B.   Reconditioning: The Village Engineer shall have the right to approve
used materials, equipment and devices provided that such materials and
equipment have been reconditioned, tested and placed in working condition. No
reconditioned materials or equipment may be employed in Class I aerobic units.
   C.   Technical Data: The Village Engineer may require that sufficient
technical data be submitted to substantiate the proposed use of any material or
assembly, and if it is determined that the evidence submitted is satisfactory
proof of performance for the use intended, the Village Engineer shall approve
its use subject to the requirements of this Chapter. The costs of all tests,
reports and investigations required under these provisions shall be paid by the
applicant.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.1002. PRETREATMENT COMPONENTS.
   A.   Any septic tank employed in the construction or repair of a Private
Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System shall meet the minimum standards for
construction established in the Illinois Private Sewage Disposal Licensing Act
and Code.
   B.   Aerobic Units: Any aerobic unit employed in the construction or repair
of an Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System discharging into a soil
absorption system shall be listed by NSF International as a Class I unit.
   C.   Effluent Filters: Any effluent filter employed in the construction or
repair of a Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System shall be designed
for the specific purpose of filtering septic tank effluent, shall be effective
in the reduction of BOD5 and Total Suspended Solids, and shall be easily
maintained.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.1003. LIFT STATIONS.
   A.   Any lift station employed in the construction or repair of a Private
Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System shall be watertight and shall be
designed to prevent floatation when emptied.
   B.   Every lift station shall be equipped with a riser extending a minimum
of four inches (4") above grade covered with a lid secured to prevent
unauthorized entry.
   C.   Pumps and Controls:
      1.   Any pump employed in the construction or repair of a Private
Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System shall be specified by its manufacturer
as an effluent or sewage pump. Pumps shall be non-automatic, operated by an
external switch or control.
      2.   Pump switches shall be sealed mercury float switches or equal. Any
pump employed in a low pressure pipe system shall be controlled by dual
switches to accurately regulate pumping volume.
      3.   Pump controls, if employed, shall be operated by mercury float
switches or equal. Duplex controls shall be wired as three float, alternating
cycles.
      4.   Electrical boxes shall be water tight and located outside of the
pump tank.
      5.   No pump shall be operated by a timing mechanism unless specifically
proposed and approved for the individual circumstance.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.1004. DISTRIBUTION DEVICES.
   Any distribution boxes employed in the construction or repair of a Private
Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System shall be constructed of concrete or
plastic.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.1005. VALVES.
   Any valve employed in the construction or repair of a Private Individual
Onsite Sewage Disposal System shall be as established by this Section.
   A.   Diversion valves shall be PVC and shall be designed with one inlet
dividing flow into either of two or more outlets, and be operated by a single
valve control.
   B.   Ball valves or gate valves in low pressure pipe systems shall be PVC.
   C.   Check valves, where specified, shall be PVC solvent joined or
compression fitting.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.1006. PIPING.
   All piping employed in the construction or repair of a Private Individual
Onsite Sewage Disposal System shall be as established by this Section or an
equivalent for the intended use as specified in the Illinois Private Sewage
Disposal Code, Section 905, Appendix A, Illustration C.
   A.   Building sewers shall be Schedule 40 PVC, four inches or greater in
diameter.
   B.   Gravity effluent lines shall be SDR 35 PVC, four inches in diameter.
   C.   Pressure supply lines shall be SDR 21 PVC, and
      1.   Two inch (2") minimum diameter on low pressure pipe systems.
      2.   One and one-half inch (1-1/2") minimum diameter to distribution
boxes.
   D.   Low pressure pipe lateral distribution piping shall be SDR 26 PVC and
one and one-quarter inch (1-1/4") minimum diameter.
   E.   Gravity lateral distribution piping shall be corrugated polyethylene
ASTM Standard F667-84 and four inch (4") minimum diameter.
   F.   Couplings, connectors and fittings shall be as appropriate for the
size, material, and use.
   G.   All fittings in pressure lines or low pressure pipe systems shall be
schedule 40 PVC pressure fittings.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.1007. FILL; AGGREGATE.
   A.   All fill material employed in the construction or repair of a private
sanitary sewage septic/soil absorption system shall be coarse sand.
   B.   All gravel employed in the construction or repair of a Private
Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System shall be sized between three-quarter
inch (3/4") and one and one-half inch (1-1/2"), and shall be washed to be
essentially free of dust, sand or other material.
   C.   All material employed in the construction or repair of a Private
Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System to separate gravel from backfill or
cover soil shall be an approved biodegradable material, such as untreated
building paper, or an appropriate geotextile. Barrier material for Private
Sanitary Sewage Septic System Types 4 and 5 shall be an appropriate geotextile
only.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.1008. BACKFILL/TOPSOIL.
   All soil material used in backfilling or covering Private Individual Onsite
Sewage Disposal System components or soil absorption areas shall be free of
rocks, clods and extraneous materials, of a suitable quality to support
vegetative cover, and requiring a minimum of landscaping.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.1009. OTHER MATERIALS.
   All material employed in the construction or repair of a Private Individual
Onsite Sewage Disposal System which is not specified in this section shall be
approved only after a review of the proposed usage by the Health Officer and/or
the Village Engineer.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
   ARTICLE XI. LAND APPLICATION
SECTION 8.1101. LAND APPLICATION PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful to apply Septage on, or to discharge effluent to the
surface of, any land within the corporate limits of the Village of Mettawa.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.1102. TREATMENT BY IRRIGATION PROHIBITED.
   Within the corporate limits of the Village of Mettawa, it shall be unlawful
for any person, firm or corporation to permit or cause to be permitted the
treatment of sanitary sewage and/or sanitary wastewater by irrigation. In
addition, no person, firm or corporation shall undertake to treat sanitary
sewage and/or sanitary wastewater by means of irrigation of any type, including
but not limited to spray irrigation.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
   ARTICLE XII. INTERPRETATION AND CONFLICT
SECTION 8.1201. MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS.
   The provisions of this Chapter, and the health regulations and ordinances of
the County of Lake shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the
promotion of public health, safety and general welfare. Whenever a provision of
this Chapter or any other applicable provisions of law, whether set forth in
this Chapter or any other applicable provisions of law imposes overlapping or
contradictory regulations or contains restrictions covering similar subject
matter, the provision which imposes higher standards or requirements for the
promotion of public health and safety of the residents of Mettawa shall
prevail.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.1202. COMPLIANCE WITH STATE AND LOCAL REQUIREMENTS.
   Compliance with this Chapter does not relieve the applicant and/or the owner
from compliance with more restrictive applicable State of Illinois and/or
Country of Lake regulations governing Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal
Systems.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.1203. (RESERVED)
   ARTICLE XIII. ENFORCEMENT
SECTION 8.1301. AUTHORITY OF THE VILLAGE ENGINEER.
   The Village Engineer is charged with the enforcement of this Chapter.
However, where enforcement and/or inspections are being undertaken and made by
the Health Officer, the Village Engineer and/or his agent need not duplicate
such efforts.
   A.   Whenever the condition of a site approved for a Private Individual
Onsite Sewage Disposal System has changed or any information considered in the
approval of a Private Individual Onsite Sewage Disposal System was omitted or
found to be false or erroneous, the Village Engineer and/or the Building
Official may revoke the approval of that site and of any construction permit
issued pursuant to the approval.
   B.   Revocation Notice: Revocation of approval shall be in writing, posted
at the site and mailed to the owner, licensed designer, and licensed
contractor, as applicable, by certified mail or nationally recognized overnight
delivery service.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.1302. RELIEF FROM PERSONAL LIABILITY.
   While they are acting for the Village of Mettawa, the Village Engineer and
the Building Official shall not be liable personally, and are hereby relieved
individually and severally from all personal liability for any damage that may
accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in
the discharge or omission of their official duties. Any suit instituted against
any officer or employee because of an act performed by the Village Engineer
and/or the Building Official in the lawful discharge of duties and under the
provisions of this Chapter shall be defended by the legal representative of the
Village until the final termination of the proceeding, except as may be
otherwise required by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village. The
Village Engineer and the Building Official shall not be liable for costs in any
action, suit, or proceedings that may be instituted in pursuance of the
provisions of this Chapter and shall be free from liability for acts performed
under any of its provisions or failure to perform, or by reason of any act or
omission in the performance of their official duties in connection therewith.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
SECTION 8.1303. SEVERABILITY.
   If any part or parts of this Chapter shall be held to be unconstitutional,
such unconstitutionality shall not affect the validity of the remaining parts
of this Chapter. The President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Mettawa
hereby declare that they would have passed the remaining parts of this Chapter
if they had known that such part or parts thereof would be declared
unconstitutional.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003)
   ARTICLE XIV. SANCTIONS
SECTION 8.1401. VIOLATION; PENALTY.
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to violate
any of the provisions of this Chapter other than Article XIII.
   B.   Any person, firm, or corporation who violates, disobeys, refuses to
comply with, or who resists enforcement of any of the provisions of this
Chapter shall be subject to a fine as set forth in Chapter 2, Village
Government, Article X, Tax, Fee, Fine and Penalty Schedules, Section
2.1003, Fine and Penalty Schedule, for each offense. For purposes of this
Section and this Chapter, each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 433, passed 9-13-2000; Am. Ord. 501, passed 8-19-2003; Am. Ord. 852,
passed 10-20-2020)
   ARTICLE XV. APPENDICES
Appendix A
   The following materials are incorporated as a part of this Ordinance for
reference purposes:
   A.   Illinois Private Sewage Disposal Licensing Act (225 ILCS 225/1 et seq.)
and Illinois Private Sewage Disposal Code (Title 77 Illinois Administrative
Code, Chapter I, Subchapter r, Part 905)
   B.   Wisconsin Mound Soil Absorption System Siting, Design, and Construction
Manual, Small Scale Waste Management Project, University of Wisconsin-Madison,
January, 1990
   C.   Wisconsin At Grade Soil Absorption System Siting, Design and
Construction Manual Small Scale Waste Management Project, University of
Wisconsin-Madison, January, 1990
   D.   Design and Installation of Low-Pressure Pipe Waste Treatment Systems,
UNC Sea Grant College Publication UNC-56-82-03, May, 1982
   All incorporated materials are available for inspection and copying at the
offices of the Lake County Health Department, Environmental Health Services.

ARTICLE I. ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
SECTION 9.101. TITLE.
   The Village Modifications in this Chapter as well as all international and
state codes adopted by reference herein, shall be known as the Building Code of
the Village of Mettawa hereinafter referred to as "Building Code" or "this
Chapter". A copy of this Chapter as well as all international and state codes
adopted by reference herein shall be kept on file for public inspection in the
offices of the Village Clerk and the Building Administrator.
(Ord. 500, passed 6-3-2003)
SECTION 9.102. ADOPTION OF CODE.
   That the 2012 International Building Code be and the same is adopted hereby
by reference, subject to the Village Modifications contained in this Chapter.
(Ord. 500, passed 6-3-2003; Am. Ord. 721, passed 6-19-2012)
SECTION 9.103. SCOPE.
   This Building Code shall regulate all matters concerning the construction,
alteration, additions, repair, removal, demolition, occupancy and maintenance
of all buildings and structures, and shall apply to existing or proposed
buildings and structures; except as such matters are otherwise provided for in
other ordinances, or in the rules and regulations authorized for promulgation
under the provisions of this Building Code. The provisions of this Article
shall be deemed the minimum requirements for the remodeling, repair or
alteration of existing buildings or structures, and the construction of new
single-family residences, offices, hotels, and all other buildings for uses
allowed in the Zoning Ordinance (
Chapter 15 of the Municipal Code of the Village of Mettawa of 2001) and their
accessory buildings.
(Ord. 500, passed 6-3-2003)
SECTION 9.104. ADMINISTRATION.
   This Building Code shall be administered and enforced by the Building
Administrator.
(Ord. 500, passed 6-3-2003)
SECTION 9.105. CODE REMEDIAL.
   This Building Code shall be construed to secure its expressed intent, which
is to insure public safety, health and welfare insofar as they are affected by
building construction, through structural strength, adequate egress facilities,
sanitary equipment, light and ventilation, and fire safety. In general the
purpose of this Chapter is to secure safety to life and property from all
hazards incident to the design, erection, repair, removal, demolition or use
and occupancy of buildings, structures or premises.
(Ord. 500, passed 6-3-2003)
SECTION 9.106. APPLICABILITY.
   A.   General: The provisions of these regulations shall cover all matters
affecting or relating to buildings and structures other than ordinary repairs
as set forth in subsection
9.106D of this Section.
   B.   Exemptions: A building or structure shall not be constructed, extended,
repaired, removed or altered without a Building Permit and/or in violation of
this Chapter, except for ordinary repairs as described in subsection
9.106F of this Section.
   C.   Other Regulations: When the provisions of this Chapter conflict with
other codes adopted by reference herein, the Village Modifications shall
supersede such other code.
   D.   Ordinary Repairs: A permit is not required for maintenance, repair and
replacement work, provided the scope of the work shall be limited to the
following:
      1.   Repair or replacement of any roof surface;
      2.   Repair or replacement of exterior wood or metal siding;
      3.   Tuck pointing and/or exterior stucco repairs;
      4.   Patching of interior plaster or plaster board;
      5.   Repair or replacement of doors or window sash in existing openings;
      6.   Repair or replacement of existing fence in same location;
      7.   Replacement of counter tops, cabinets, sinks and appliances not
requiring alteration to plumbing, heating, air conditioning or electrical
system; and
      8.   Installation of a storage building not exceeding one hundred fifty
(150) square feet which has no dimension over twelve (12) feet and no plumbing,
electrical or heating systems.
      9.   Ordinary repairs to existing structures and replacement with the
same kind of materials may be made without application or notice to the
Building Administrator; however, such repairs and replacement shall not include
cutting away of or the removal or cutting of any structural beam or bearing
support, or the removal or change of any required means of egress, or the
rearrangement of parts of a structure affecting the exitway requirements; nor
shall ordinary repairs include the addition to, alteration of, replacement or
relocation of any structural member, stand pipe, water supply, sewer, drainage,
drain leader, gas, soil, waste, vent or similar piping, electrical wiring or
mechanical or other work affecting the public health or general safety.
(Ord. 500, passed 6-3-2003)
SECTION 9.107. CONSTRUCTION HOURS RESTRICTED.
   Construction or alteration operations shall be carried on within the Village
on weekdays from 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. and on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays
from 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.
(Ord. 500, passed 6-3-2003)
SECTION 9.108. INSTALLATION OF ELEVATORS AND SERVICE EQUIPMENT.
   A.   When the installation, extension, alteration or repair of an elevator
or moving stairway is specifically controlled by the provisions of this
Building Code, it shall be unlawful to use such equipment until a certificate
has been issued therefor by the Building Administrator or other agency having
jurisdiction.
   B.   When the installation, extension, or alteration of mechanical
equipment, refrigeration, air conditioning or ventilating apparatus, plumbing,
gas piping, electric wiring, heating system or any other equipment is
specifically controlled by the provisions of this Building Code, it shall be
unlawful to use such equipment until a certificate has been issued therefor by
the Building Administrator.
(Ord. 500, passed 6-3-2003)
SECTION 9.109. CHANGE IN EXISTING USE.
   A.   Unlawful Use: The initial or continued occupancy or use of a building
or structure, or of a part thereof, constructed in violation of any regulation
contained in this Chapter, shall be deemed a violation and subject to the
penalties prescribed in this Chapter.
   B.   Continuation of Existing Use: The legal use and occupancy of a
structure approved and constructed in accord with existing ordinances, may be
continued without change, except as may be specifically covered in this Chapter
and
Chapter 15 of the Mettawa Municipal Code or as may be deemed necessary by the
Building Administrator for the general safety and welfare of the occupants and
the public.
   C.   Change in Use: It shall be unlawful to make any change in the use or
occupancy of any structure which would subject it to any special provision of
this Building Code without approval of the Building Administrator, and his
certification that such structure meets the intent of the provisions of law
governing building construction for the proposed new use and occupancy, and
that such change does not result in any greater hazard to public safety or
welfare. Further, any proposed change shall be in accordance with the
provisions of Chapter 15 of the Mettawa Municipal Code of 2001 (Zoning
Ordinance).
(Ord. 500, passed 6-3-2003)
