attest his signature thereon and he shall make his report containing the
recommendation of the Plan Commission to the entire membership of the Plan
Commission and the President and Board of Trustees. If the Chairman does not
sign the Minor Subdivision Plat within seven (7) days of his receipt thereof,
the plat of subdivision shall be reviewed by the members of the Plan Commission
during a regular or special meeting thereof and, following such meeting. In all
events the Chairman shall make his report containing the recommendation of the
Plan Commission to the entire membership of the Plan Commission and the
President and Board of Trustees. If the recommendation of the Plan Commission
is to approve the plat, the Chairman shall sign the plat and the Secretary
shall attest his signature thereon and forward the original thereof to the
President and Board of Trustees with the recommendation of the Plan Commission.
            ii.   If a variation from the application of the Zoning Ordinance
or waiver of portions of the Building Code will be sought after approval of the
plat for recording as submitted, then the Chairman of the Plan Commission shall
require that the plat of subdivision shall be reviewed by the members of the
Plan Commission during a regular or special meeting thereof and, following such
meeting, the Chairman shall make his report containing the recommendation of
the Plan Commission to the entire membership of the Plan Commission and the
President and Board of Trustees. If the recommendation of the Plan Commission
is to approve the plat, the Chairman shall sign the plat and the Secretary
shall attest his signature thereon and forward the original thereof to the
President and Board of Trustees with the recommendation of the Plan Commission.
         b.   Following the review of the plat of each such Minor Subdivision,
the Secretary or the Chairman of the Plan Commission will send the President
and Board of Trustees a copy of the Chairman's written report containing the
recommendation of the Plan Commission regarding the plat.
      2.   President and Board of Trustees consideration. Upon its receipt of a
written recommendation from the Chairman of the Plan Commission, such minor
subdivision plat shall be acted upon by the President and Board of Trustees.
(Am. Ord. 591, passed 9-18-2007; Am. Ord. 860, passed 6-10-2021)
ARTICLE IV. PROCEDURE — MAJOR SUBDIVISIONS
SECTION
   
16.401   Submission and Review of Plats for Major Subdivisions
   
16.402   Avoidance of Preliminary Plat Procedures
SECTION 16.401. SUBMISSION AND REVIEW OF PLATS FOR MAJOR SUBDIVISIONS.
   A.   Preparation Requirements — Preliminary Plats of Major Subdivisions.
Preliminary plats for major subdivisions shall be prepared containing the
material indicated for minor subdivisions in Subsection A of Section 16.05 of
this Chapter, as well as the following:
      1.   Streets and public ways. All streets shown on the plat shall be
named in conformity with the street naming plan of the Village and all street
names shall be shown. The width and location of roads, streets, alleys, the
Mettawa Trail, and other public ways shall be shown. The full widths of streets
bounding the proposed subdivision (with their names), and the widths and names
of intersecting streets in the property immediately adjacent, shall be shown.
      2.   If applicable, the plat shall have lettered upon it a statement of
dedication properly conveying all lands dedicated for public use.
   B.   Filing Fee. At the time original application is made for a major
subdivision, resubdivision or consolidation of a parcel or parcels of property
within the Village, the applicant shall pay such fees to the Village Clerk in
the amounts thereof established by resolution of the President and Board of
Trustees from time to time which shall include an estimated amount to reimburse
the Village its costs for engineering and legal review by the Village Engineer
and the Village Attorney. A current copy of such resolution shall be maintained
in the office of the Village Clerk. No application for subdivision shall be
accepted by the Village Clerk or the Secretary until all such fees have been
paid, with the understanding that no subdivision plat shall be filed with the
Lake County Recorder of Deeds for recordation until all such engineering and
legal fees have been fully reimbursed the Village by the applicant.
   C.   Filing Requirements for Preliminary Plat of Major Subdivision. No
application for approval of a preliminary plat of subdivision shall be accepted
unless accompanied by a completed application form, the filing requirements
listed herein, and any other documents requested by the Plan Commission,
including but not limited to preliminary engineering and a soil classification
study. There must be adherence to all filing requirements at least 30 days
prior to the date of Plan Commission review. The following documents must
accompany the filing of such application:
      1.   Preliminary plat of subdivision prepared and sealed by a land
surveyor duly licensed by the State of Illinois (five full-size copies on
standard sheets not larger than 24 x 36 inches and drawn to a scale of not less
than one inch equals 50 feet and ten 11 x 17 inch reduced copies).
      2.   The filing requirements contained in Subsection C of Section
16.301 of this Chapter, except that the above preliminary plat of subdivision
shall suffice for the plat of subdivision.
      3.   Tree preservation plan. An approved tree preservation plan, as more
specifically described elsewhere in this Municipal Code, is required whenever
there will be construction of bonded improvements, demolition activity, earth
moving, or other construction activity related to the subdivision. When no such
activity is related to the proposed subdivision, a statement signed by the
applicant indicating that no trees will be removed prior to issuance of a
building permit may be submitted instead of a tree preservation plan.
   D.   Action on Preliminary Plat.
      1.   Plan Commission review.
         a.   If, by reason of the general character or topography of the
property to be subdivided, or of any lot to be created by such subdivision, it
appears likely to the Village Engineer and the Plan Commission that a variation
from the application of the Zoning Ordinance or waiver of a portion of the
Mettawa Building Code will be sought after approval of the final plat for
recording as submitted, then the Plan Commission may reject the entire
preliminary plat of subdivision, or may direct that such lots as to which it
appears likely that a variation will be sought be excluded therefrom.
         b.   In the event the said plat does not conform to the provisions of
this Chapter or other pertinent ordinances, including but not limited to the
zoning ordinance, or is not consistent with the Comprehensive Plan or with the
general design and layout of similar areas of the Village, the subdivider may
then make such changes as are specified or required by the Plan Commission.
         c.   Following its review of such preliminary plat, if there is
consensus that the plat should be given approval, the Plan Commission will
request the Village Engineer to review the preliminary engineering plans and
specifications and prepare a written report thereon.
      2.   Following its approval of the engineering plans and specifications,
the Plan Commission shall give the preliminary plat its approval and file a
written report thereof with the President and Board of Trustees.
         a.   The approval of a preliminary plat by the Plan Commission shall
be effective for a period of one (1) year.
         b.   Thereupon the Plan Commission shall certify said action by
stamping or lettering on said plat the following certificate:
“Preliminary approval by the Plan Commission of the Village of Mettawa,
Illinois, this day of ___________, A.D. 20___, subject to all conditions or
preliminary approval as set forth in the Plan Commission’s report to the
President and Board of Trustees, shall be effective for one (1) year from the
date hereof.
                                                            
         Chairman”
   E.   Major Subdivision, Final Plat Procedure.
      1.   Filing deadline. Within 180 days after the date of the approval of
the preliminary plat by the President and Board of Trustees, the subdivider
shall submit to the Plan Commission the final plat of a Major Subdivision for
approval and recording as described hereinbelow.
         a.   Time extensions. Upon the request of the subdivider made within
the first 150 days following the date of the approval of the preliminary plat
as aforesaid, and for good cause shown, the Plan Commission may extend the time
for submitting the final plat for approval for an additional 90 days, provided
that only one such extension may be granted with respect to any given
subdivision proposal.
         b.   Revocation of preliminary plat approval. The subdivider's failure
to submit a final plat to the Plan Commission for approval within the time or
extension thereof set forth above shall operate as an automatic revocation of
the approval of the preliminary plat, and the subsequent subdivision of the
same property shall proceed only upon application to the Village as set forth
herein for original applications.
      2.   Filing Requirements for final plat of major subdivision. These
requirements are cumulative to and augment the filing requirements for a
preliminary plat of a major subdivision. At the time of filing of final plat of
major subdivision, the subdivider shall submit an engineering, drainage and
grading plan containing detailed plans and specifications along with a natural
resource opinion, theretofore approved by the Village Engineer, for the
installation, construction and design of all Bonded Improvements, including but
not limited to street pavements, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, trails and
pathways, fire hydrants, water mains, storm sewers and storm water storage
facilities, street lights and other bonded improvements detailing the existing
centerline elevations of all streets and alleys in the proposed subdivision and
the centerline elevations of proposed pavements [Elevations shall refer to
U.S.G.S. datum]. Profiles shall be drawn to a horizontal scale of not more than
one inch equals 50 feet and vertical scale of not less than one inch equals
five feet, which plans and profiles shall be prepared by an engineer licensed
by the State of Illinois in accord with all applicable codes and ordinances of
the Village as well as with the more detailed regulations contained below:
         a.   All proper certificates and seals as required by law shall be
shown on the subdivision plat including the signature and seal of the Illinois
registered land surveyor who prepared the plat.
         b.   No engineering, drainage, and grading plan shall be deemed
approved unless the certificate of the Village Engineer is reflected thereon,
certifying that the bonded improvements described thereon in the owner/
subdivider statement and the plan meet the minimum requirements of this Chapter
and all other applicable ordinances of the Village, which certificate shall
include the Village Engineer's estimate of the cost of such improvements, as
well as the costs of engineering and inspection.
   F.   Plan Commission Recommendation. Provided the final plat meets the
conditions (if any) set forth upon which the preliminary plat had been approved
and is otherwise in accord with the preliminary plat and with all applicable
regulations of this Subdivision Code, the Secretary of the Chairman will make
and send the President and Board of Trustees a written report containing the
Plan Commission recommendation.
   G.   Subdivider's Agreement. At the time of the approval of any final plat
of a major subdivision, the plat shall not be signed by the Village President
or attested by the Village Clerk until the President and Board of Trustees
shall be in receipt of the subdivider's written agreement in form approved by
the Village Attorney wherein the subdivider agrees: To install and construct
all bonded improvements in accordance with all applicable Codes and ordinances
of the Village; to establish responsibility for operation and maintenance of
the detention area in a homeowners' association or other private entity
pursuant to a declaration of covenants approved as part of the subdivider's
agreement; to pay all required fees in accordance with the requirements of the
ordinances of the Village; and to make all required donations and financial
guarantees, including reimbursement of the fees and charges of the Village
Attorney and Village Engineer. While a subdivider's agreement may be amended
(by mutual agreement of the subdivider and the President and Board of Trustees)
to extend the time for commencing and completing bonded improvements, the
subdivider's agreement shall contain the approximate date when installation of
bonded improvements will commence and a reasonable date for completion of said
bonded improvements, subject to the condition that, at the latest, the
improvements shall be completed within two (2) years of the date of the
recordation of the final form of a major plat of subdivision by the Lake County
Recorder of Deeds following the President and Board of Trustees' approval
thereof. If not otherwise specifically addressed or otherwise provided in the
subdivider's agreement, the following shall apply to all major and minor
subdivisions:
      1.   The subdivider may freely assign, transfer or convey real property
within a platted subdivision, but such assignment, transfer or conveyance shall
not affect the principal obligation of the subdivider to perform the
obligations set forth in the subdivider's agreement, which shall bind the
assignees and successors in interest of the subdivider;
      2.   The bonded improvements associated with a building permit for a
model home need not be constructed and installed prior to the issuance of such
permit, provided that such model home is otherwise constructed in accordance
with the applicable ordinances of the Village;
      3.   If the subdivider has deposited a financial guarantee with the
Village Treasurer, the issuer of such financial guarantee will pay all
attorney's fees and other costs incurred by the Village in enforcing collection
of such financial guarantee in the event that the issuer fails to honor the
Village's demand for payment under the terms of such financial guarantee;
      4.   Unless the subdivider has deposited with the Village Treasurer a
financial guarantee in a form meeting the requirements of this Chapter and
approved by the Village Attorney, no building permit associated with a lot in a
major subdivision shall be issued until all of the bonded improvements are
constructed, fully completed and approved for use by the President and Board of
Trustees, including but not limited to: The Mettawa Trail and street pavement
systems, including bituminous base, asphalt binder course, stormwater detention
systems and street inlets, and storm sewers or swales;
      5.   No certificate of occupancy associated with a lot in a major
subdivision shall be issued until grading of the street parkways across the
frontage of the subject lot and final grading and installation of top soil,
seeding/sod, and landscaping of the common areas, if any, in the entire major
subdivision have been completed and installed; and
      6.   If constructed, no sewer and water utilities within the subdivision
shall be connected to the sewer and water utilities belonging to the Village,
except in accordance with the applicable provisions of the municipal code and
upon payment of the connection fees required therein.
   H.   President and Board of Trustees Consideration. Upon receipt of a
recommendation from the Plan Commission, such final plat of major subdivision
shall be acted upon by the President and Board of Trustees. If approved by the
President and Board of Trustees it is understood that such approval is
conditioned upon the owner/subdivider depositing the financial guarantee and
executing the subdivider's agreement in the form approved by the Village
Attorney, unless noted to the contrary by the President and Board of Trustees.
   J.   Financial Guarantee. In the event an applicant seeks to have a building
permit associated with a lot in a major subdivision issued prior to bonded
improvements being constructed, accepted and approved for use, the subdivider
must deposit a suitable financial guarantee, which includes the maintenance
guarantee, with the Village Treasurer to guarantee the Village the completion
of all bonded improvements as determined by the Village Engineer in accordance
with the subdivider's agreement and the ordinances of the Village, together
with all other commitments made by the subdivider; which financial guarantee
shall be either a letter of credit (in a form to be approved by the Village
Attorney), or subdivision bond, or cash. Any such letter of credit must be
irrevocable and made by a sound and reputable bank whereby a sum of money is
set aside and restricted as payment for the performance of specific obligations
by the subdivider:
      1.   The financial guarantee submitted in accordance with this Subsection
to guarantee the completion of bonded improvements shall be in an amount equal
to one hundred fifteen percent (115%) of the Village Engineer's estimated cost
of installing and constructing said bonded improvements and shall provide as
follows:
         a.   An expiration date not less than two (2) years from the date of
issuance or an express provision that such financial guarantee will not expire
prior to completion and acceptance of said bonded improvements by the President
and Board of Trustees;
         b.   That the financial or insurance company issuing the financial
guarantee shall give written notice by certified or registered mail to the
Village Clerk and the Village Engineer not less than forty-five (45) days
before the expiration of the financial guarantee, which financial guarantee
shall not expire absent such notice;
         c.   That failure of the subdivider to complete the bonded
improvements secured by such financial guarantee prior to the scheduled
completion date shall be considered a default by the subdivider and the issuing
institution;
         d.   That failure of the subdivider to submit a successor financial
guarantee in accordance with this Subsection, to be effective upon expiration
of the initial financial guarantee deposited with the Village Treasurer, shall
be unlawful and considered a default by the subdivider and the issuing
institution;
         e.   That the financial guarantee shall be irrevocable;
         f.   That (in the case of a payout instrument) the principal amount of
the instrument will not be discharged or reduced by the issuer except upon
written certificate of the Village Engineer that such surety may be discharged
or reduced in a specified amount in accordance with Paragraph 3 below; and
         g.   That the issuer will pay all attorneys' fees and other costs
incurred by the Village in enforcing collection of such financial guarantee in
the event that the issuer fails to honor the Village's demand for payment under
the terms of such financial guarantee.
      2.   Notwithstanding the foregoing, a standby financial guarantee
submitted in accordance with this Subsection to guarantee the completion of
bonded improvements may be reduced in amount prior to completion and acceptance
of such bonded improvements in the sole discretion of the President and Board
of Trustees as follows:
         a.   Provided he approves of the installation of any given
improvement, following his inspection and review of the installation of the
bonded improvements and usual and customary waivers of lien attendant thereto,
the Village Engineer shall recommend reduction of the surety to the President
and Board of Trustees; and
         b.   Upon its receipt of the recommendation of the Village Engineer,
the said President and Board of Trustees may authorize the reduction of the
amount of a financial guarantee — it being understood that the total amount of
the maintenance guarantee shall not be reduced but shall be retained in the
financial guarantee, to be held by the Village for the two (2) year period
following approval and acceptance of the improvements by the President and
Board of Trustees in order to guarantee the installation and materials used in
constructing the bonded improvements.
      3.   In the event the financial guarantee submitted in accordance with
this Subsection to guarantee the completion of the bonded improvement is a
"pay-out" instrument, it is understood that such financial guarantee shall be
reduced periodically to reflect payment by the subdivider for the bonded
improvements as follows:
         a.   Provided he approves of the installation of any given bonded
improvement, the Village Engineer, following his inspection and review of the
installation of the bonded improvements and usual and customary waivers of lien
attendant thereto, shall authorize payment to be made from the financial
guarantee; and
         b.   In no event shall the Village engineer authorize a reduction in
the amount of the maintenance guarantee, which shall be retained in the
financial guarantee, to be held by the Village for the two (2) year period
following approval and acceptance of the improvements by the President and
Board of Trustees in order to guarantee the installation and materials used in
constructing the bonded improvements.
      4.   In the event a financial guarantee submitted in accordance with this
Subsection shall be discharged upon acceptance by the President and Board of
Trustees of all bonded improvements for which said financial guarantee was
submitted, a maintenance financial guarantee (in form of cash, bond, or letter
of credit) guaranteeing said improvements against defects in materials or
workmanship in the amount of fifteen percent (15%) of the actual costs of said
improvements shall be deposited with the Village by the owner/subdivider to be
effective for a period of two (2) years from the date of such acceptance of
said bonded improvements.
(Am. Ord. 591, passed 9-18-2007)
SECTION 16.402. AVOIDANCE OF PRELIMINARY PLAT PROCEDURES.
   An applicant may waive the right to preliminary approval process and may
instead file all of the data required in this Article for such approval at the
same time as such applicant files engineering plans and the final plat.
However, before undertaking the formal procedures outlined in this Subdivision
Code, an applicant is urged to submit a tentative plat and discuss the proposal
with the Village Engineer to ascertain the requirements affecting the
subdivision.
ARTICLE V. ENFORCEMENT
SECTION
   
16.501   Recording of Plats
   
16.502   Installation Requirements - Construction Methods - Bonded Improvements
   
16.503   Issuance of Building Permits and Certificates of Occupancy
   
16.504   Required Approvals
   
16.505   Recapture Ordinance
   
16.506   Penalty
SECTION 16.501. RECORDING OF PLATS.
   A.   No plat of any subdivision of land within the corporate limits of the
Village of Mettawa shall be entitled to recordation by the Lake County Recorder
of Deeds or have any validity until it shall have been approved in the manner
prescribed by law and this Subdivision Code.
   B.   Within six (6) months after the date of final approval of such plat by
the President and Board of Trustees, and provided that all fees and costs have
theretofore been paid, at the sole cost and expense of the subdivider, the
Village shall cause such plat to be recorded in the office of the Recorder of
Deeds of Lake County, Illinois, and thereafter shall retain the original plat
in and as part of the official records of the Village. In the absence of a
provision in a development agreement to the contrary, if such final plat of
subdivision is not so recorded within said six (6) month period from and after
the final approval thereof by the President and Board of Trustees, the said
President and Board of Trustees approval thereof shall be deemed null and void,
and of no further force and effect; and in such case any subsequent attempt to
record such plat shall proceed only upon a new application for subdivision in
the manner set forth in this Chapter.
   C.   Recordation of an approved plat shall constitute acceptance by the
President and Board of Trustees of ownership of or easement rights, as the case
may be, associated with land shown thereon as provided for or dedicated to
public use, unless otherwise indicated.
(Ord. 591, passed 9-18-2007)
SECTION 16.502. INSTALLATION REQUIREMENTS AND CONSTRUCTION METHODS — BONDED
IMPROVEMENTS.
   A.   Plans and Specifications To Be Approved. Before commencement of
construction of bonded improvements required by this Chapter or a development
agreement, as the case may be, all plans and specifications for such bonded
improvements shall be reviewed by and must receive the approval of the Village
Engineer and must thereafter receive the approval of the Village Board.
   B.   All Construction To Be Approved. It shall be unlawful to install and/or
construct any bonded improvement in a manner inconsistent with applicable
regulations of the Municipal Code, including but not limited to the following:
      1.   Sidewalks. In order to aid in the preservation of the rural
character of the Village, sidewalks shall not be installed unless their
installation and construction have first been approved by the President and
Board of Trustees.
      2.   Mettawa Trail. No portion of this trail system shall be altered or
extended unless provisions are made for the concurrent installation thereof,
the plans for installation have first been approved by the President and Board
of Trustees, and construction approved by the Village Engineer.
      3.   Pavements. No street shall be paved unless provisions are made for
the concurrent installation of other street appurtenances contained in the
engineering plans approved by the Village Engineer, including storm sewers or
swales herein required.
      4.   Fire hydrants. Provided public potable water is available within
1000 feet of the subdivision and, in the event no existing fire hydrant is
located within four hundred (400) feet (measured along the extended ingress to
and egress from a lot-in-depth and thence along the center line of the
previously existing street upon which said lot-in-depth has frontage) of the
buildable area of any proposed lot-in-depth, fire hydrants shall be installed
at such locations(s) as are designated by the Village Engineer, one of which
hydrants shall be located within the said four hundred (400) foot distance. All
such fire hydrants shall be connected by a minimum six (6) inch diameter water
main constructed from an existing main having not less than a six (6) inch
diameter.
      5.   Storm water facilities.
         a.   A storm sewer or swale system shall be constructed throughout the
entire subdivision which shall be separate and independent of all septic
systems and which shall provide an efficient outlet for storm water after
collection thereof. Storm sewers or swales shall be installed and constructed
on both sides of a street or on one (1) side of the street and no street shall
be paved unless provision is made for the concurrent installation of other
street appurtenances contained in the engineering plans approved by the Village
Engineer, including construction of storm sewers or swales for the full length
of the street pavement. Only storm sewers located within the public right-of-
way or within an easement in favor of the Village shall be public storm sewers.
         b.   Private storm sewers. In the event the Village Engineer shall
determine that storm drainage to a public storm sewer or swale is required for
a lot-in-depth or privately maintained street because of the topography of the
land in and around the parcel being subdivided, private storm sewers shall be
installed within the subdivision pursuant to plans approved by the Village
Engineer.
         c.   Private maintenance of storm water detention areas. Storm water
detention areas (including basins and below ground detention structures)
required to comply with the Village's Storm Water Management Ordinance will be
sited in common area specifically set aside for such use. The responsibility
for operation and maintenance of the detention area and special stormwater
drainage facilities shall be that of a homeowners' association or other private
entity pursuant to a declaration of covenants required as part of the
subdivision approval and included in the subdivider's agreement.
      6.   Street signs. Metallic street name signs shall be erected on
metallic posts at each intersection. The type of sign, its location and its
erection shall be determined by the Village Engineer, who shall be guided by
the provisions of the current edition of the "State Manual for Uniform Traffic
Control Devices", to the extent applicable.
      7.   Street lights and public utilities.
         a.   Street Lights. Standard street lights shall be installed,
however, the subdivider may request use of an ornamental/decorative street
light other than the standard street lights approved for installation by
Commonwealth Edison. Such ornamental/decorative street lighting system shall be
submitted for the approval of the Village Engineer. The maintenance, repair,
and replacement of such ornamental/decorative street lighting system shall be
that of a homeowners' association or other private entity pursuant to a
declaration of covenants required as part of the subdivision approval.
Electrical energy for such lights shall be located underground and charges for
electricity for such lights placed in the public right-of-way shall be the
responsibility of the Village.
         b.   All other utility distribution lines, for telephone and gas and
electric services, to be installed, as well as cable television cable, shall be
placed underground within easements or dedicated public rights-of-way.
   C.   Inspection at Subdivider's Expense. During the course of construction,
all improvements proposed to be made under provisions of this Chapter shall be
inspected by the Village Engineer or his duly designated agent. All fees and
costs established by the President and Board of Trustees by Resolution adopted
from time to time hereafter in connection with such inspection shall be
reimbursed to the Village by the subdivider.
   D.   Maintenance and Service of Private Roads, Sewers, Common Areas, and/or
Detention/retention Ponds. Private roads and easements shall be serviced and
maintained by the owners thereof; no officer, agent or employee of the Village
shall at any time service or maintain or offer or agree to service or maintain
any private road or easement or any part thereof. When a subdivision includes a
private road, common area, sewer, and/or a detention/retention pond, a covenant
shall be drafted and recorded requiring the establishment of a suitable method
(which may include the creation of an homeowners' association) to provide for
the maintenance of such private road, common area, sewer, and/or detention/
retention pond.
(Ord. 591, passed 9-18-2007)
SECTION 16.503. ISSUANCE OF BUILDING PERMITS AND CERTIFICATES OF OCCUPANCY.
   Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this Chapter, whether
or not a financial guarantee has been deposited with the Village Engineer, with
respect to any final plat of subdivision approved by the Village President and
Board of Trustees and recorded with the Recorder of Deeds of Lake County:
   A.   No building permit shall be issued unless the extent of street
improvements shall be adequate for vehicular police and fire equipment access
to the proposed building site; and
   B.   No certificate of occupancy for any building in the subdivision shall
be issued prior to the completion of all such bonded improvements and all
public improvements have been formally accepted and approved for use by the
President and Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 591, passed 9-18-2007)
SECTION 16.504. REQUIRED APPROVALS.
   Where any approval is required of them in this Chapter, nothing in this
Chapter shall be construed as requiring any or all of the Plan Commission, the
Village Engineer and the Village Board to give any such approval if plans and
specifications or other matters requiring their approval do not comply with
applicable provisions of this Chapter or a given development agreement, as the
case may be.
(Ord. 591, passed 9-18-2007)
SECTION 16.505. RECAPTURE ORDINANCE.
   A.   Recapture. If: 1) a municipal ordinance of the village or the President
and Board of Trustees require the installation of any water mains, sanitary
sewers, storm drains, roadways or other public facilities; and 2) in the
opinion of the corporate authorities such facilities may be used for the
benefit of additional property not controlled by the person of whom
installation is required; and 3) such water mains, sanitary sewers, storm
drains, roadways or other facilities are to be dedicated to the public, the
corporate authorities may, by ordinance, require other property which benefits
by such facilities to contribute a fair and reasonable portion of certified
costs of installation, including engineering costs, to the installing party.
      1.   The village shall have the sole authority to determine the
following:
         a.   The amount of interest, if any, to be charged to a benefited
property owner (not to exceed 10 percent simple interest/annum);
         b.   The method by which the costs are to be certified;
         c.   The fair and reasonable apportionment of costs;
         d.   The party responsible for collection of the apportioned costs;
         e.   The service charge due the village for establishment of the
recapture ordinance;
         f.   The amount of time (not to exceed 10 years) that the ordinance is
to remain in effect;
         g.   The amount by which the apportioned costs are to be reduced due
to depreciation;
         h.   The method by which the ordinance is to be enforced;
         i.   Any other matters pertinent to the adoption of the ordinance.
   B.   Recordation. Any ordinance adopted pursuant to this section shall be
recorded against all parcels to be benefited by the facilities with the
recorder of deeds of Lake County. It shall be the responsibility of the
installing owner to record the ordinance whether so stated in the recapture
ordinance or not.
   C.   Notification to Property Owners. The recording of the ordinance, in
this manner, shall serve to notify persons interested in such additional
property of the fact that there will be a charge in relation to such property
for the connection to and use of the facilities constructed under the
ordinance.
   D.   Hold Harmless. The village shall be held harmless by the installing
property owner and successors against any claims made on account of the
adoption of the recapture ordinance, any attempted implementation of the
ordinance and any failure on the part of the village or its officials to
collect the recapture amount.
   E.   Collection of Recapture Fee - Interest - Payment to Developer. At the
time when an application is filed with the Village for a building permit for
the construction of a building upon any portion of the other property or when
an application is filed with any other governmental agency for a utility tap-on
permit for connection of such other property to such public improvement,
directly or indirectly, (whichever event first occurs), the Village shall
collect from such titleholder of record of such portion of other property the
amount of the recapture fee calculated with interest in accordance this section
from the date of completion of such public improvements to the date of
collection. Upon receipt of the recapture fee, the Village shall issue its
receipt therefor and reimburse the developer the total developer cost portion
of the recapture fee, plus the interest collected.
   F.   Creation of Special Service Areas - New Local Sewer Systems. When and
if the Village ascertains that the titleholders of records of non-commercial
and/or non-industrial uses of other property within the corporate limits of the
Village desire sanitary sewer service, such service shall be available only
upon the titleholders of record of such non-commercial and/or non-industrial
other property paying for the installation of a local sewer system. In such
cases, Mettawa may require that funding of construction of the local sewer
system and the payment therefor by these titleholders of record of such other
property shall be by means of one or more special service areas created by the
Village, subject to the Village receiving recapture as set forth in the
pertinent recapture agreement. In all cases and prior to the creation of the
SSA, the titleholder of record of each parcel of other property who seeks a
sanitary sewer connection shall execute a restrictive covenant in favor of the
County and the Village by which such titleholder of record agrees that, absent
County and Village consent, no titleholder of record of such parcel shall
thereafter extend any sanitary sewer easement or extend or permit any extension
of any sanitary sewer service to any other land and that no such titleholder of
record shall seek to develop the land except in accordance with the authorized
density thereof reflected on the parcel chart attached to the recapture
agreement.
   G.   Other Fees. The collection of the recapture fee contemplated shall be
in addition to and over and above any and all other building permit fees, water
tap-on fees, sewer connection fees, and/or any or all other applicable fees
required to be paid by the titleholder of record of any of the other property
pursuant to the ordinances of the Village and other regulatory agencies, and/or
Statutes of the State of Illinois.
   H.   Costs Expended by the Village. Whenever the Village of Mettawa has
caused the oversizing of sewer and/or water mains or otherwise provided for
access thereto and/or provided for sewer and/or water service to be afforded an
owner or owners of any property or properties other than the owner installing
the improvement, the Village shall have the right to reimbursement and
recapture of its costs in connection with such oversizing or affording such
service to such owner. Accordingly, no such owner shall thereafter apply to the
Village for a permit, or have a right to tap into or make connection with such
sewer line or water main or shall be required by any ordinance to connect or
tap into said improvement without first reimbursing the Village its costs with
interest thereon at a rate to be determined by the Village in accordance with
Section A(l)(a) above from the date of the installation to the date of such
application and payment of such recapture costs. Upon such application by such
owner, the Village Engineer shall compute and certify to such applicant the
pro-rata cost of construction of that section of such sewer and/or water main
and, before issuing any permit to tap into or connect therewith, shall receive
such pro-rata amount of such recapture reimbursement on behalf of the Village;
and upon receipt remit the same to the Village Treasurer for distribution in
the manner authorized by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of
Mettawa.
   I.   Village Engineer determination of Contribution. The determination of
the Village Engineer as to the amount of such recapture contribution shall, in
the absence of willful fraud or misconduct, be conclusive. Such recapture
payment shall be in addition to and exclusive of any other fees required and
fixed by any other ordinance as inspection or permit fees for connection with
or tap into such sewer or water mains.
(Ord. 614, passed 11-18-2008; Am. Ord. 766, passed 9-19-2014)
SECTION 16.506. PENALTY.
   A.   It shall be unlawful for a titleholder of record of other property or
any other person, firm or corporation having an interest in any other property
or any portion thereof, or any contractor, agent or representative of such
titleholder of record or person, firm or corporation to make any connection
with any of the public improvements which are the subject of a recapture
agreement without first making application for a permit therefor and paying the
amount required under such recapture agreement.
   B.   Any such person, firm or corporation upon conviction of a violation of
Subsection A of this Section
16.506, shall be fined in an amount as set forth in Chapter 2, Village
Government, Article X, Tax, Fee, Fine and Penalty Schedules, Section
2.1003, Fine and Penalty Schedule. Each day that such connection exists in
contravention of this Section shall be a separate violation. The Village shall
have the right without further notice or permission to remove all such
connections so made.
(Ord. 614, passed 11-18-2008; Am. Ord. 852, passed 10-20-2020)
ARTICLE VI. CONSTRUCTION
SECTION
   
16.601   Rules and Definitions
SECTION 16.601. RULES AND DEFINITIONS.
   A.   The language in the text of this Chapter shall be interpreted in
accordance with the following rules of construction:
      1.   The singular number includes the plural number, and the plural the
singular;
      2.   The word "shall" is mandatory; the word "may" is permissive; and
      3.   The masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter.
   B.   Whenever hereafter in this Chapter the following words and phrases are
used, they shall, for the purposes of this Chapter, have the meanings
respectively ascribed to them in this Subsection, except when the context
otherwise indicates.
      "Applicant" Any person, firm or corporation who files an application for
a building permit or for zoning consideration.
      "Arterial Street" A street that provides or that will provide for traffic
with a high degree of continuity.
         a.   "Major arterial street" An arterial street that provides or that
will provide for fast or heavy traffic of considerable continuity and that will
be used primarily as a traffic artery for intercommunication between large
areas in and near the Village, and shall include those streets designated or
that may be designated "arterial street", by the State of Illinois and those
streets shown or that may be shown as "major street", on the Major Street Plan.
         b.   "Minor arterial street" An arterial street that carries or that
will carry traffic from minor streets to arterial streets, and shall include
the principal entrance streets of a subdivision development and the primary
circulating streets therein.
      "Bonded Improvements" All public improvements and those privately owned
improvements (e.g. stormwater retention and/or detention ponds, special
stormwater drainage, street pavement, and walkways within private streets) and
other improvements including but not limited to: The Mettawa Trail and street
pavement systems, bituminous base, asphalt binder course, curb, gutter and
street inlets, and storm sewers or swales.
      "Building Code"
Chapter 9 of the municipal code.
      "Building Official" The Building Official of the Village.
      "Certificate of Occupancy" For purposes of this Chapter, the certificate
of occupancy issued pursuant to the building and zoning regulations contained
in Chapters
15 and
16 of the municipal code upon completion of construction. For purposes of this
Chapter, "certificate of occupancy" includes a partial certificate of
occupancy.
      "Comprehensive Plan" or "Comprehensive Plan" The official Comprehensive
Plan of the Village of Mettawa of 1977, as amended.
      "County" The County of Lake, an Illinois unit of local government.
      "Cul-de-sac" The area intended for vehicle turnaround located at the
termination of a dead-end street.
      "DBH" The diameter of a tree at breast height.
      "Developer" The Village or other person, firm or corporation which pays
for the construction of a public improvement.
      "DNR" or "Illinois Department of Natural Resources" The Department of
Natural Resources of the State of Illinois.
      "Engineer's Estimate" The estimate of the Village Engineer of the cost of
bonded improvements, which shall automatically change to become identical to
the actual cost of the bonded improvements set forth in the contract or
contracts entered into for the construction and installation of such bonded
improvements.
      "Engineering Plans or Final Engineering Plans" The Public Improvement
installation and construction specifications, consistent with the Preliminary
Engineering Plans, including, as a minimum, the following plans for: The
Mettawa Trail and public streets, including pavement, curb, gutter, swales and
landscaping; wetlands mitigation and protection; stormwater management,
including final drainage and grading; public sanitary sewer lines and potable
water mains, if any; and appurtenances to all of the foregoing.
      "Established lot width" The average lot width established on one side of
an entire block where at least sixty percent (60%) of the lots have a lot width
greater than that required by the zoning ordinance.
      "Financial Guarantee" In order to assure the Village that the
construction and installation of bonded improvements will occur in a timely
fashion and workmanlike manner, the deposit with Village made in accordance
with the regulations contained in this Chapter and held by the Village
Treasurer — whether such deposit is in the form of a subdivision bond, letter
of credit or cash — the amount of which shall include the amount of the
maintenance guarantee.
      "Front lot line" With respect to any lot other than a Lot-in-Depth, the
line thereof coextensive with the right-of-way line of any adjacent street.
      "Grand Total Cost" The total developer cost, plus an additional twenty
percent (20%) payable to the Village to reimburse the Village for legal,
engineering and clerical expenses and an additional three percent (3%) payable
to the Village to reimburse the Village for the Village's costs of collection
of the recapture fee.
      "Local Sewer System" A grid of sanitary sewer lines and lateral sewers
(including any extension of a trunk line that is necessary to connect the grid
to a trunk line, force main or an extension of either or both) as well as all
necessary rights-of-way or easements therefor, constructed in accordance with
all applicable County standards, regulations and ordinances within a
subdivision or other land proposed to receive sanitary sewer service in order
to collect sanitary sewerage generated by residents of such subdivision or
land, which grid is connected directly into the a trunk line, force main or an
extension of either or both constructed by a developer and to which a recapture
agreement pertains.
      "Lot" A portion of platted land measured, set apart, and subdivided as a
distinct parcel having its principal frontage upon a street and created and
delineated upon a duly approved plat of subdivision or resubdivision and so
recorded by the Recorder of Deeds of Lake County, Illinois.
      "Lot depth" The mean horizontal distance between the front and the rear
lot lines. For a lot-in-depth, lot depth shall be the average distance between
the rear lot line and the non-stem portion of the front lot line.
      "Lot-in-depth" A lot of record, most of which is adjacent to and located
behind another lot of record and derives its only access to a street by a Stem.
      "Maintenance Guarantee" In order to insure the Village against risk in
defects in materials and/or workmanship associated with the construction and
installation of bonded improvements, a portion of the financial guarantee equal
to fifteen percent (15%) of the engineer's estimate, held by the Village for
two years following acceptance of the improvements by the President and Board
of Trustees.
      "Major Subdivision" Any subdivision which involves installation and/or
construction of bonded improvements.
      "Mettawa Trail" The formal name of a path owned by the Village for
equestrian, pedestrian and bicyclist use by the public and located as shown on
a plat of subdivision within a twenty (20) foot wide public right-of-way
easement dedicated to the Village as a planned continuation of the path from
off-site, which path shall have a minimum width of eight (8) feet and a maximum
width of twelve (12) feet and shall be constructed as a public improvement.
      "Minor Street" A street in a residential area that is or that will be
used primarily for access to abutting residential properties.
      "Minor Subdivision" Any subdivision which does not involve the
installation and/or construction of bonded improvements.
      "Municipal Code" The Municipal Code of the Village of Mettawa of 2001, as
same may be amended from time to time hereafter.
      "Official Village standards" Those standards of installation,
construction and design on file for public inspection in the office of the
Village Engineer, as the same may be adopted and amended from time to time by
the President and Board of Trustees.
      "Other Property" Displayed on a Recapture Area Map and/or Chart, the
parcels of land lying within the corporate limits of the Village that are
entitled to or are benefited by a public improvement constructed and installed
subject to a recapture agreement duly entered into in accordance with the terms
of this Chapter, the titleholder of record of which is not otherwise assessed
or required to pay for such public improvement at the time of the installation
thereof.
      "Parcel Chart" A list identifying the parcels of land eligible to receive
sanitary sewer service and specifying the maximum P.E. that each such parcel
will be entitled to deliver to the County sanitary sewer system.
      "P.E." or "Population Equivalents" The permissible sewage flow from land
eligible for sanitary sewerage service. One P.E. is equivalent to 100 gallons
per day.
      "PIN" A permanent index number assigned to each parcel of land within the
County that identifies each such parcel for assessment and other purposes.
      "Plan Commission" The Plan Commission of the Village.
      "Plat" or "Plat of Subdivision" A plat of subdivision.
      "Preliminary Engineering Plans" The Public Improvement installation and
construction conceptual specifications of the bonded improvements required for
any given subdivision.
      "Private Sanitary Sewage Septic System" or "System" A sewage treatment
and disposal system which infiltrates treated wastewater into soil where the
projected daily flow is less than 1,500 gallons.
      "Private Street" Other than a Public Street, the entire right-of-way of
every roadway thoroughfare or other place conveyed and/or reserved by
dedication as a roadway and/or driveway not for use by the general public.
      "Public Improvement" Any improvement, found on or described in final
engineering plans or related documents, which shall be dedicated to use by the
general public and/or the ownership of which shall be conveyed to the Village,
including but not limited to: The Mettawa Trail and street pavement, curb,
gutter and walkways within a right-of-way dedicated to or for the use of the
Village or other governmental agency; the Mettawa Trail; and, if any, sanitary
sewer and potable watermain.
      "Public Street" The entire right-of-way or width of every road, way,
thoroughfare, or place conveyed and/or dedicated by prescription or plat or
other instrument for use by the general public or conveyed and/or dedicated to
the Village or other public agency and that is or may be open to the use of the
public for the primary purpose of vehicular traffic but shall not be deemed to
include the Mettawa Trail or any other such right-of-way twenty (20) feet or
less in width.
      "Rear lot line" The line of any lot that is most distant from and
opposite of the front lot line thereof.
      "Recapture Agreement" An agreement between the Village and a developer or
between the County and the Village (as developer) whereby the developer who
pays in whole or in part for the installation of a public improvement or
portion thereof is entitled to receive full or partial re-payment of such
developer's costs of such installation.
      "Recapture Area Map and Chart" Attached hereto and hereby made a part of
a recapture agreement, being a map and/or a chart containing a PIN for each
parcel of Other Property and which may include the maximum P.E. of each such
parcel of Other Property that is eligible to receive sanitary sewerage service.
      "Recapture Fee or Recapture" The fee collected by the Village calculated
and charged on a proportionate basis in accordance with the formulae contained
in Section
16.505 of this Chapter.
      "Receipt" Issued by the Village, an acknowledgment of payment of
recapture fees that are allocated to a given parcel of other property.
      "Side lot line" Any lot line of a lot between a front lot line and the
rear lot line thereof unless such lot line lies opposite a front lot line, in
which case such lot line shall be a rear lot line.
      "Special Service Area" or "SSA" A statutory special service area
established by the Village and, in the case of a recapture agreement, created
to pay for the costs of necessary public improvements other than those
constructed subject to the recapture agreement and, in the case of a recapture
agreement for sanitary sewer to pay for the costs of necessary public
improvements to the County's sewer system, such as the costs of constructing a
local sewer system.
      "Stem" The extended portion of a lot-in-depth which provides access to a
street. For purposes of this Subdivision Code, a stem of a lot-in-depth is
considered the lot's principal street frontage. No portion of a stem shall be
considered a yard. In the case of lots-in-depth created by subdivision approved
prior to January 1, 2000, the extended portion of a lot-in-depth may consist of
an easement providing access to a street.
      "Street" Any public street or private street.
      "Subdivider's Agreement" or "Development Agreement" An agreement entered
into by and between the Village and an owner (or subdivider) of land to govern
the development of such land and the construction of improvements associated
therewith.
      "Subdivision" Any change or rearrangement in the boundaries or division
lines of any lot, parcel, piece or tract of land, or the division of such lot,
parcel, piece or tract of land into one or more lots, including the
consolidation or rearrangement in the boundaries or division lines of any lot,
parcel, piece or tract of land into a single lot.
      "Subdivision Code" This
Chapter 16 of the municipal code.
      "Tableland" Land where the cross slope in any direction does not exceed
ten percent (10%).
      "Through Lot" A Lot, other than a corner lot, which has frontage on two
(2) streets.
      "Total Developer Cost" The developer's costs of constructing the public
improvement determined by actual contracts entered into by the developer for
labor (including engineering) and materials, with the understanding that, in
the absence of any such contract or contracts, the Village Engineer's estimate
of such costs shall be used to determine the total developer cost.
      "Village" The Village of Mettawa, an Illinois municipal corporation and
home rule unit as described in the Illinois Constitution.
      "Village Attorney" The Village Attorney of the Village.
      "Village Board" or "President and Board of Trustees" The President and
Board of Trustees of the Village of Mettawa.
      "Village Clerk" The Village Clerk of the Village.
      "Village Engineer" The Village Engineer of the Village.
      "Village President or Mayor" The Village President or Mayor of the
Village.
      "Water Course" A river, creek, lake, or floodway.
      "Zoning Ordinance"
Chapter 15 of the municipal code.
      "Zoning Ordinance District Map" The official "Zoning Ordinance District
Map" of the Zoning Ordinance, as amended and as the same may be amended from
time to time.
(Ord. 591, passed 9-18-2007; Am. Ord. 614, passed 11-18-2008)
ARTICLE VII. VARIATIONS
SECTION
   
16.701   Variations and Exceptions
SECTION 16.701. VARIATIONS AND EXCEPTIONS.
   A.   Variations from these regulations shall not be granted as a right.
However, the Plan Commission may recommend and the President and Board of
Trustees may grant variations from the regulations contained in this
Subdivision Code in specific cases which do not affect the general plan or the
spirit of the Subdivision Code.
   B.   Exceptions from the regulation that every lot shall have four (4) sides
may be approved when the applicant demonstrates that a four-sided lot is not
feasible because of peculiar topographical conditions, abutting lots of record
or abutting parcels not owned directly or indirectly by the applicant, or the
presence of pre-existing buildings not owned directly or indirectly by the
applicant. When granted, any given such exception shall not be construed as a
variation from the terms and conditions set forth in this Chapter.
(Am. Ord. 591, passed 9-18-2007)
ARTICLE VIII. VIOLATIONS
SECTION
   
16.801   Penalty
SECTION 16.801. PENALTY.
   A.   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to file or attempt
to file a plat of subdivision with the Lake County Recorder of Deeds for
recordation without first having secured the approval of the President and
Board of Trustees of the Village in accord with the procedures set forth in
this Chapter.
   B.   Every person, firm or corporation found by a court of law to have
violated any provision of this section shall be guilty of a business offense
and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine as set forth in Chapter 2,
Village Government, Article X, Tax, Fee, Fine and Penalty Schedules, Section
2.1003, Fine and Penalty Schedule, for each offense; and a separate offense
shall be deemed to have been committed on each day during or on which a
violation occurs or continues.
(Am. Ord. 488, passed 7-16-2002; Am. Ord. 852, passed 10-20-2020)

ARTICLE I. GENERAL
SECTION 17.101. RULES AND DEFINITIONS.
   A.   Rules of Word Construction. The language set forth in the text of this
Article shall be interpreted in accordance with the following rules of
construction:
      1.   The singular number includes the plural number and the plural the
singular.
      2.   The word “shall” is mandatory; the word “may” is permissive.
      3.   The masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter.
   B.   Definitions. Whenever in this Article the following words and phrases
have been used, they shall, for the purposes of this Chapter, have the meanings
respectively ascribed to them in this subsection, except when the context
otherwise indicates:
      AFFILIATE. A person who (directly or indirectly) owns or controls, is
owned or controlled by, or is under common ownership or control with another
person.
      CABLE ACT. The Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, 47 USC Section
532, et seq., as now and hereafter amended.
      CABLE OPERATOR. A telecommunications carrier providing or offering to
provide “cable service” within the Village as that term is defined in the Cable
Act.
      CABLE SERVICE. That term as defined in 47 U.S.C. § 522(6).
      CORPORATE AUTHORITIES. The President and Board of Trustees of the
Village.
      EXCESS CAPACITY. The volume or capacity in any existing or future duct,
conduit, manhole, handhole or other utility facility within the public way that
is or will be available for use for additional telecommunications facilities.
      FCC or FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION. The Federal administrative
agency, or lawful successor, authorized to regulate and oversee
telecommunications carriers, services and providers on a national level.
      GRANTEE. Encompasses both licensees and franchisees, being a recipient of
either a license or a franchise.
      GROSS REVENUES. All consideration of any kind or nature, including but
not limited to cash, credits, property, and in-kind contributions received by
the holder for the operation of a cable or video system to provide cable
service or video service within the holder's cable service or video service
area within the Village as well as.
         a.   Recurring charges for cable or video service;
         b.   Event-based charges for cable service or video service, including
but not limited to pay-per-view and video-on-demand charges;
         c.   Rental of set top boxes and other cable service or video service
equipment;
         d.   Service charges related to the provision of cable service or
video service, including but not limited to activation, installation, and
repair charges;
         e.   Administrative charges related to the provision of cable service
or video service, including but not limited to service order and service
termination charge;
         f.   Late payment fees or charges, insufficient funds check charges
and other charges assessed to recover the costs of collecting delinquent
payments;
         g.   A pro rata portion of all revenue derived by the holder or its
affiliates pursuant to compensation arrangements for advertising or for
promotion or exhibition of any products or services derived from the operation
of the holder's network to provide cable service or video service within the
Village, utilizing the following formula: The number of subscribers within the
corporate limits of the Village divided by the total number of subscribers in
relation to the relevant regional or national compensation arrangement;
         h.   Compensation received by the holder that is derived from the
operation of the holder's network to provide cable service or video service
with respect to commissions that are received by the holder as compensation for
promotion or exhibition of any products or services on the holder's network,
such as a "home shopping" or similar channel, subject to subsection (ix);
         i.   In the case of a cable service or video service that is bundled
or integrated functionally with other services or capabilities or applications,
the portion of the holder's revenue attributable to such other services or
capabilities or applications shall be included in the gross revenue, unless the
holder can reasonably identify the division or exclusion of the revenue from
its books and records that are kept in the regular course of business;
         j.   The service provider fee permitted by 220 ILCS 5/21-801(b); and
         k.   Revenue of an affiliate of a holder shall be included in the
calculation of gross revenues to the extent the treatment of the revenue as
revenue of the affiliate rather than the holder has the effect of evading the
payment of the fee permitted by 220 ILCS 5/21-801(b) which would otherwise be
paid by the cable service or video service.
   It is understood, however, gross revenues do not include any of the
following:
         a.   Revenues not actually received, even if billed, such as bad debt,
subject to 220 ILCS 5/21-801(c)(1)(vi);
         b.   Refunds, discounts, or other price adjustments that reduce the
amount of gross revenues received by the holder of the State-issued
authorization to the extent the refund, rebate, credit, or discount is
attributable to cable service or video service;
         c.   Regardless of whether the services are bundled, packaged, or
functionally integrated with cable service or video service, any revenues
received from services not classified as cable service or video service,
including, without limitation, revenue received from telecommunication
services, information services, or the provision of directory or Internet
advertising, including yellow pages, white pages, banner advertisement, and
electronic publishing or any other revenues attributed by the holder to
noncable service or nonvideo service in accordance with the holder's books and
records and records kept in the regular course of business and any applicable
laws, rules, regulations, standards, or orders;
         d.   The sale of cable services or video services for resale in which
the purchaser is required to collect the service provider fee from the
purchaser's subscribers to the extent the purchaser certifies in writing that
it will resell the service within the Village and pay the fee permitted by 220
ILCS 5/21-801(b) with respect to the service;
         e.   Any tax or fee of general applicability imposed upon the
subscribers or the transaction by a city, State, Federal, or any other
governmental entity and collected by the holder of the State-issued
authorization and required to be remitted to the taxing entity, including sales
and use taxes;
         f.   Security deposits collected from subscribers; and
         g.   Amounts paid by subscribers to "home shopping" or similar vendors
for merchandise sold through any home shopping channel offered as part of the
cable service or video service.
      HOLDER or CABLE OR VIDEO PROVIDER. A person or entity that has received
authorization to offer or provide cable or video service from the Illinois
Commerce Commission pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/21-401.
      ICC or ILLINOIS COMMERCE COMMISSION. The State administrative agency, or
lawful successor, authorized to regulate and oversee telecommunications
carriers, services and providers in the State of Illinois.
      OTHER WAYS. The highways, streets, alleys, utility easements or other
rights-of-way, within the Village, but under the jurisdiction and control of a
governmental entity other than the Village.
      OVERHEAD FACILITIES. Utility poles, utility facilities and
telecommunications facilities located above the surface of the ground,
including the underground supports and foundations for such facilities.
      PEG. Public, education and governmental.
      PEG ACCESS SUPPORT FEE. The amount paid under this Chapter and 220 ILCS
5/21-801(d) by the holder to the Village for the service areas within its
territorial jurisdiction.
      PERSON. Includes corporations, companies, associations, joint stock
companies or associations, firms, partnerships, limited liability companies and
individuals and includes their lessors, trustees and receivers.
      PUBLIC STREET. Any highway, street, alley or other public right of way
for motor vehicle travel under the jurisdiction and control of the Village
which has been acquired, established, dedicated or devoted to highway purposes
not inconsistent with telecommunications facilities.
      PUBLIC WAY. Includes all public streets and utility easements, as those
terms are defined herein, now or hereafter owned by the Village, but only to
the extent of the Village's right, title, interest or authority to grant a
license or franchise to occupy and use such streets and easements for
telecommunications facilities.
      SERVICE. The provision of "cable service" or "video service" to
subscribers and the interaction of subscribers with the person or entity that
has received authorization to offer or provide cable or video service from the
Illinois Commerce Commission pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/21-401.
      SERVICE PROVIDER FEE. The amount paid under this Chapter and 220 ILCS 5/
21-801 by the holder to a Village for the service areas within its territorial
jurisdiction.
      STATE. The State of Illinois.
      SURPLUS SPACE. The portion of the usable space on a utility pole which
has the necessary clearance from other pole users, as required by the orders
and regulations of the Illinois Commerce Commission, to allow its use by a
telecommunications carrier for a pole attachment.
      TELECOMMUNICATIONS CARRIER. Every person that directly or indirectly
owns, controls, operates or manages plant, equipment or property within the
Village, used or to be used for the purpose of offering telecommunications
service.
      TELECOMMUNICATIONS FACILITIES. The plant, equipment and property,
including but not limited to, cables, wires, conduits, ducts, pedestals,
antennae, electronics and other  appurtenances used or to be used to transmit,
receive, distribute, provide or offer telecommunications services.
      TELECOMMUNICATIONS PROVIDER. Includes every person who provides
telecommunications service over telecommunications facilities without any
ownership or management control of the facilities.
      TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICE. The providing or offering for rent, sale or
lease, or in exchange for other value received, of the transmittal of voice,
data, image, graphic and video programming information between or among points
by wire, cable, fiber optics, laser, microwave, radio, satellite or similar
facilities, with or without benefit of any closed transmission medium.
      TELECOMMUNICATIONS SYSTEM. Shall have the same meaning as
“Telecommunications Facilities,” defined above.
      UNDERGROUND FACILITIES. Utility and telecommunications facilities located
under the surface of the ground, excluding the underground foundations or
supports for overhead facilities.
      USABLE SPACE. The total distance between the top of a utility pole and
the lowest possible attachment point that provides the minimum allowable
vertical clearance as specified in the orders and regulations of the Illinois
Commerce Commission.
      UTILITY EASEMENT. Any easement owned by the Village and acquired,
established, dedicated or devoted for public utility purposes not inconsistent
with telecommunications facilities.
      UTILITY FACILITIES. The plant, equipment and property, including but not
limited to the poles, pipes, mains, conduits, ducts, cables, wires, plant and
equipment located under, on or above the surface of the ground within the
public ways of the Village and used or to be used for the purpose of providing
utility or telecommunications services.
      VIDEO SERVICE. Video programming and subscriber interaction, if any, that
is required for the selection or use of such video programming services, and
which is provided through wireline facilities located at least in part in the
public right-of-way without regard to delivery technology, including Internet
protocol technology. This definition does not include any video programming
provided by a commercial mobile service provider defined in 47 U.S.C. § 332(d)
or any video programming provided solely as part of, and via, service that
enables users to access content, information, electronic mail, or other
services offered over the public Internet.
      VILLAGE. The Village of Mettawa.
      VILLAGE PROPERTY. Includes all real property owned by the Village, other
than public streets and utility easements as those terms are defined herein,
and all property held in a proprietary capacity by the Village, which are not
subject to right-of-way licensing and franchising as provided in this Chapter.
      WORK. Undertaking any, some, or all of the following: construction,
installation, operation, disconnection, relocation, removing, maintaining, or
otherwise locating telecommunications facilities in, under, over or across any
public way of the Village.
(Ord. 348, passed 1-8-97; Am. Ord. 593, passed 11-19-2007)
SECTION 17.102. PURPOSE.
   The purpose and intent of this Chapter is to:
   A.   Establish a local policy concerning telecommunications providers and
services;
   B.   Establish clear local guidelines, standards and time frames for the
exercise of local authority with respect to the regulation of
telecommunications providers and services;
   C.   Promote competition in telecommunications;
   D.   Minimize unnecessary local regulation of telecommunications providers
and services;
   E.   Encourage the provision of advanced and competitive telecommunications
services on the widest possible basis to the businesses, institutions and
residents of the Village;
   F.   Permit and manage reasonable access to the public ways of the Village
for telecommunications purposes on a competitively neutral basis;
   G.   Conserve the limited physical capacity of the public ways held in
public trust by the Village;
   H.   Assure that the Village's current and ongoing costs of granting and
regulating private access to and use of the public ways are fully paid by the
persons seeking such access and causing such costs;
   J.   Secure fair and reasonable compensation to the Village and the
residents of the Village for permitting private use of the public ways;
   K.   Assure that all telecommunications carriers providing facilities or
services within the Village comply with the ordinances, rules and regulations
of the Village;
   L.   Assure that the Village can continue to fairly and responsibly protect
the public health, safety and welfare; and
   M.   Enable the Village to discharge its public trust consistent with
rapidly evolving federal and state regulatory policies, industry competition
and technological development.
(Ord. 348, passed 1-8-97)
SECTION 17.103. REGISTRATION.
   Except as otherwise provided herein, any telecommunications carrier having
any telecommunications facilities within the corporate limits of the Village
and offers or provides
telecommunications services to customer premises within the Village shall
register with the Village on forms provided by the Village pursuant to Article
II of this Chapter.
(Ord. 348, passed 1-8-97)
SECTION 17.104. TELECOMMUNICATIONS LICENSE.
   Except as otherwise provided therein, it shall be unlawful for a
telecommunications carrier to work for the sole purpose of providing
telecommunications service to persons and areas outside the Village without
first obtaining a license for the use of such public ways from the Village
pursuant to Article III.
(Ord. 348, passed 1-8-97)
SECTION 17.105. TELECOMMUNICATIONS FRANCHISE.
   Except as otherwise provided herein, it shall be unlawful for a
telecommunications carrier to work in, under, over or across any public way of
the Village, and to also provide telecommunications service to persons or areas
within the Village, without first obtaining a franchise license for the use of
such public ways from the Village pursuant to Article IV of this Chapter.
(Ord. 348, passed 1-8-97)
SECTION 17.106. CABLE TELEVISION FRANCHISE.
   Except as otherwise provided herein, it shall be unlawful for a
telecommunications carrier to work in any public way of the Village for the
purpose of providing cable service to persons in the Village without first
obtaining a cable franchise license from the Village as provided in Article V.
(Ord. 348, passed 1-8-97)
SECTION 17.107. APPLICATION TO EXISTING FRANCHISE ORDINANCES AND AGREEMENTS.
   This Chapter shall have no effect on any existing franchise ordinance or
franchise agreement until:
   A.   The expiration of said franchise ordinance or agreement; or
   B.   The effective date of an amendment to an unexpired franchise ordinance
or franchise agreement, unless both parties agree to defer full compliance to a
specific date not later than present expiration date.
(Ord. 348, passed 1-8-97)
SECTION 17.108. PENALTIES.
   A.   Any person found guilty of violating, disobeying, omitting, neglecting
or refusing to comply with any of the provisions of this Chapter shall be fined
in an amount as set forth in Chapter 2, Village Government, Article X, Tax,
Fee, Fine and Penalty Schedules, Section
2.1003, Fine and Penalty Schedule.
   B.   A separate and distinct offense shall be deemed committed each day on
which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 348, passed 1-8-97; Am. Ord. 852, passed 10-20-2020)
SECTION 17.109. OTHER REMEDIES.
   Nothing in this Chapter shall be construed as limiting any judicial remedies
that the Village may have, at law or in equity, for enforcement of this
Chapter.
(Ord. 348, passed 1-8-97)
SECTION 17.110. SEVERABILITY.
   If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or other portion of
this Chapter, or its application to any person, is, for any reason, declared
invalid, in whole or in part by any court or agency of competent jurisdiction,
said decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof.
(Ord. 348, passed 1-8-97)
ARTICLE II. REGISTRATION OF TELECOMMUNICATIONS CARRIERS AND PROVIDERS
SECTION 17.201. REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   All telecommunications carriers having telecommunications facilities within
the corporate limits of the Village and all telecommunications carriers or
providers who offer or provide telecommunications service to customer premises
within the Village shall register with the Village on forms provided by the
Village Clerk which shall include the following:
   A.   The identity and legal status of the registrant, including any
affiliates;
   B.   The name, address and telephone number of the officer, agent or
employee responsible for the accuracy of the registration statement;
   C.   A description of registrant's existing or proposed telecommunications
facilities within the Village;
   D.   A description of the telecommunications service that the registrant
intends to offer or provide, or is currently offering or providing, to persons,
firms, businesses or institutions within the Village;
   E.   Information sufficient to determine whether the registrant is subject
to public way licensing or franchising under this Chapter;
   F.   Information sufficient to determine whether the transmission,
origination or receipt of the telecommunications services provided or to be
provided by the registrant constitutes an occupation or privilege subject to
any municipal telecommunications tax, utility message tax or other occupation
tax imposed by the Village;
   G.   Information sufficient to determine that the applicant has applied for
and received any certificate of authority required by the Illinois Commerce
Commission to provide telecommunications services or facilities within the
Village;
   H.   Information sufficient to determine that the applicant has applied for
and received any construction permit, operating license or other approvals
required by the Federal Communications Commission to provide telecommunications
services or facilities within the Village; and
   J.   Such other information as the Village Clerk may reasonably require.
(Ord. 348, passed 1-8-97)
SECTION 17.202. REGISTRATION FEE.
   Each application for registration as a telecommunications carrier or
provider shall be accompanied by a fee as set forth in Chapter 2, Village
Government, Article X, Tax, Fee, Fine and Penalty Schedules, Section
2.1002, Fee Schedule.
(Ord. 348, passed 1-8-97; Am. Ord. 852, passed 10-20-2020)
SECTION 17.203. PURPOSE OF REGISTRATION.
   The purposes of registration under this Article II are:
   A.   To provide the Village with accurate and current information concerning
the telecommunications carriers and providers who offer or provide
telecommunications services within the Village, or that own or operate
telecommunication facilities within the Village;
   B.   To assist the Village in enforcement of this Chapter;
   C.   To assist the Village in the collection and enforcement of any
municipal taxes, franchise fees, license fees or charges that may be due the
Village; and
   D.   To assist the Village in monitoring compliance with local, State and
Federal laws.
(Ord. 348, passed 1-8-97)
ARTICLE III. TELECOMMUNICATIONS LICENSE
SECTION 17.301. TELECOMMUNICATIONS LICENSE.
   A telecommunications license shall be required of any telecommunications
carrier who desires to work in specific public ways of the Village for the sole
purpose of providing telecommunications services solely to persons or areas
outside the Village.
(Ord. 348, passed 1-8-97)
SECTION 17.302. LICENSE APPLICATION.
